    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">On reflection, it seemed the forest had prepared a welcome for its guest:</l>
    3845<l n="b">The gift it offered was the profusion of blossoming flowers so beautifully spread before him.</l>
    .<l n="c">With wavering fronds* and red petals, the flame trees,</l>
    .<l n="d">Like lips eagerly seeking pleasure, awaited him.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">With its many valleys, it was as grand and idyllic as the Nandana grove.*</l>
    3850<l n="b">Its delightful caves, quite extraordinary in their perfection, were its ornaments.</l>
    .<l n="c">Among its trees of many kinds were the heavenly coral-trees,* fresh and blossoming,</l>
    .<l n="d">With a canopy of trailing,* leafy fronds unfurling.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">A river flowed delightfully into the crevices of the craggy peaks.</l>
    3855<l n="b">Streams spouted from the rocks, forming a pond like a small sea.</l>
    .<l n="c">The rock face was of such brilliance that it challenged the beauty of the ocean,</l>
    .<l n="d">With scattered, flowering pandanus draped* everywhere over its lovely stones.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Pārtha’s heart was captivated as he climbed higher and higher up Mount Hima.</l>
    3860<l n="b">He became ever more amazed as he gazed upon its celestial beauty.</l>
    .<l n="c">It towered over the realm of the Bhāratas,</l>
    .<l n="d">Looking down on the steep valleys of the eastern mountain with its one hundred holy bathing pools.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Over a ravine so deep and impenetrable* that it was lost to view, clouds gathered,</l>
    3865<l n="b">To merge into its gleaming sulphur, caressing it, veiling it,</l>
    .<l n="c">Forming a bright shining halo of light,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Pregnant with the soft rain that is always betokened* by the voice of the thunder.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">A gleam of water marked the location of the spotless river.*</l>
    3870<l n="b">Indeed here was the ‘Gateway of the Ganges’,* guarding the secret of its purity.</l>
    .<l n="c">‘I will go* there’, he thought, and set off, making his way down</l>
    .<l n="d">Along a narrow, rugged path, strewn with boulders, through the sharp and jagged ravines.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">So arduous was it, that it hardly seemed possible a mere mortal could penetrate its depths and reach the bottom,</l>
    3875<l n="b">Unless he were a perfect sage or an excellent priest who had put aside worldly concerns.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Thus it was proof of the true excellence of this son of Pāṇḍu,</l>
    .<l n="d">That, engaged as he was in striving for the welfare of the world, he came there with ease.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">And so it was that Pārtha came there to that remote river,*</l>
    3880<l n="b">And beheld the well-spring of the River Ganges, utterly flawless and without stain,</l>
    .<l n="c">Flowing from a fissure in its unfathomable depths, its eddying waters gushed forth,</l>
    .<l n="d">Like the emanation of the moon, giving life to all the world.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a"> On reaching it, the prince was filled with great peace,*</l>
    3885<l n="b">As he gazed upon the clear water of the Ganges, the water of life,</l>
    .<l n="c">For indeed it was ever the means to assuage the despairing heart.</l>
    .<l n="d">Descending to the source* of holy water, he bathed in its waters and purified himself.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    3890<div type="canto" n="4">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus Pārtha came to those sacred waters.*</l>
    .<l n="b">As he immersed himself in the waters of the source of that river, possessed of sanctifying power.</l>
    .<l n="c">Its full-flowing waters truly cleansed his mind, </l>
    .<l n="d">As he recited incantations and performed his devotions.</l>
    3895</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">He concentrated his mind on the immaterial presence of Śiwa,*</l>
    .<l n="b">Arising from the eight-petalled lotus, and firmly established* in the river.</l>
    .<l n="c">The essence of the sun* was invoked into the firmament,</l>
    .<l n="d">As, absorbed* in meditation, he became one in union with the sacred symbol.*</l>
    3900</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">A beautiful woman appeared in the presence of the prince.</l>
    .<l n="b">Her perfection was such that she seemed to be the younger sister of Beauty itself, bringing love.</l>
    .<l n="c">She was indeed the month of spring, the embodiment of all that is lovely.</l>
    .<l n="d">Her sweetness held the longed-for charms of the moon.</l>
    3905</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Clearly she would arouse the bemused poet, wandering in pursuit of beauty, from his reverie.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Like the fall of a fine misty rain, her enchanting hair-knot diffused its fragrance.</l>
    .<l n="c">Her ear-rings shone all the while, revealing sudden flashes of lightning,</l>
    .<l n="d">And the glow of her shining face ever enhanced her radiance.</l>
    3910</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Pārtha had now finished his dawn worship,*</l>
    .<l n="b">And his heart seemed to stop as he saw her appear as if from nowhere.</l>
    .<l n="c">None other than the Goddess of the Hima mountain and the River Jāhnawī was she,</l>
    .<l n="d">And now he became more convinced that she was a vision.*</l>
    3915</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Where are you bound, little sister? gently he asked,</l>
    .<l n="b">‘In journeying to this mountain, where I travel on pilgrimage to the sacred waters,</l>
    .<l n="c">I had not thought it would also be the destination of those who wish to abandon themselves to the pursuit of Beauty.</l>
    .<l n="d">Yet you are a jewel, Beauty itself, my wondrous one.*</l>
    3920</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a"> ‘How foolish I am, making bold to presume that you could only be properly*</l>
    .<l n="b">Depicted as the riches of a garden offering its beauty:</l>
    .<l n="c">Your teeth gleam with the allure of <foreign>śrīdanta</foreign> flowers,</l>
    .<l n="d">And [red] <foreign>handul</foreign> flowers are always as one with your gums.</l>
    3925</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘The striking beauty of the <foreign>katirah</foreign> flower finds refuge in your lips,</l>
    .<l n="b">And in your eyes rests the dark beauty of the blue lotus.</l>
    .<l n="c">In your neck is the slenderness of the fresh <foreign>jangga</foreign> vine, its shoots unfurling,</l>
    .<l n="d">And I cannot but think, my lady, that the <foreign>mangunəng</foreign> has taken on the form of your lovely hair-band.</l>
    3930</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘Your slender body is a blossoming <foreign>priyaka.</foreign> </l>
    .<l n="b">Your arms put to shame the tendrils of the delightful <foreign>aśoka,</foreign></l>
    .<l n="c">Your calves disturb the fragrant pandanus,</l>
    .<l n="d">While your full breasts imitate* the rounded, ivory coconuts.’</l>
    3935</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Thus did Pārtha sing her praises with sweet words.</l>
    .<l n="b">Understanding his allusion, the maiden said:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘O my Lord! Your perfection* indeed exceeds that of mortal men.</l>
    .<l n="d">For you have come here to this place, where I have never before seen a soul.</l>
    3940</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">‘Your mighty deed is great, even incomparable, </l>
    .<l n="b">You have succeeded in penetrating the inaccessible Hima mountain.</l>
    .<l n="c">It is the highest degree of excellence, and </l>
    .<l n="d">You are fitting to be the refuge of those who seek the prosperity of the world.’</l>
    3945</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Thus she said, soothingly addressing kind and friendly words to him.</l>
    .<l n="b">And Phalguṇa, with gentle words respectfully replied:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘Dear maiden, who are you, O beautiful one, who comes here?</l>
    .<l n="d">Tell me truthfully, great is my concern [for you]!</l>
    3950</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">‘Dear maiden, are you, little sister, a goddess in immaterial form?</l>
    .<l n="b">Because all that is charming waits upon you,</l>
    .<l n="c">The flowers all seek refuge with you.*</l>
    .<l n="d">Clearly they lie in wait here to scratch you, that you might see how they long to attend upon you.</l>
    3955</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">‘Truly the incarnation of the entrancing beauty of the fourth month, are you,</l>
    .<l n="b">The ethereal deity of the sea of honey in bodily form.</l>
    .<l n="c">It is as if to seek to express the marvels of the ocean in poetry</l>
    .<l n="d">Or to ascribe beauty to the mountains, would cause confusion.</l>
    3960</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">‘Further, my dear, is it not fruitless for you to stay so pitifully </l>
    .<l n="b">In this inaccessible, remote place, all alone?</l>
    .<l n="c">Though you seem undaunted, are you not fearful to stay in these wooded hills,</l>
    .<l n="d">Where lions, elephants, snakes and tigers lie in wait?’</l>
    3965</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">In this way the prince questioned her closely.</l>
    .<l n="b">The one addressed so sweetly, answered him truthfully:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘My lord, listen to me, your servant,</l>
    .<l n="d">I am a woman, called Ulupuy, beset by love.</l>
    3970</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">‘I will tell you why I have taken on the form of a woman.</l>
    .<l n="b">There is a king, His Majesty, Korawya, a renowned and illustrious mighty serpent,</l>
    .<l n="c">Who alone is so awesome in his power</l>
    .<l n="d">That his irresistible valour is without equal in the three worlds.</l>
    3975</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">‘His kingdom too is of extraordinary, outstanding splendour</l>
    .<l n="b">Because of the lustre of its countless gems and jewels.</l>
    .<l n="c">Like Indra’s heaven, its beauty is without flaw,</l>
    .<l n="d">And by dint of its very nature, <foreign>parijāta</foreign> and <foreign>kalpawr̥kṣa</foreign> trees grow there.*</l>
    3980</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">‘Moreover, even heaven is inferior to it, its beauty rivalled</l>
    .<l n="b">By the unique fashioning of the underworld.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Truly, it is a creation of Lord Brahma himself,</l>
    .<l n="d">Unparalleled, for he has given his full attention to its creation.</l>
    3985</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">‘This then is where the foremost king of the snakes dwells in contentment.</l>
    .<l n="b">All vassal snakes are loyal to him,</l>
    .<l n="c">And as for me, I am the daughter of the snake king,</l>
    .<l n="d">And from time immemorial, I have never known the least sorrow.</l>
    3990</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="5">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘My father has so lavished upon me the quintessence of supreme happiness,</l>
    .<l n="b">That I found myself unable to take any pleasure in anything, so sated* was I by such infinite bliss.</l>
    3995<l n="c">I could not resist searching out the peace of this lonely, secluded place,</l>
    .<l n="d">But upon reaching here, suddenly I came upon you, seeking union with the god in the River Jāhnawī.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘And thus I was smitten by violent passions, wounded by Smara’s fiery arrow.</l>
    .<l n="b">It is only by tasting* the flow of your sweetness that my desire and longing can find respite.</l>
    4000<l n="c">For the goddess Ratih, Goddess of Love, has so enflamed the feelings of this yearning, lovesick woman,</l>
    .<l n="d">Who hopes for the excellent ambrosia of your love, for you are the embodiment of the God of Love himself.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘Moreover, could it possibly be fitting for you to live in the forest, staying in the undergrowth in such a pitiable condition,</l>
    .<l n="b">Eager to conceal yourself, seeking shelter under overhanging rocks, emaciated, unkempt and lack-lustre?</l>
    4005<l n="c">How can you find enjoyment, resting on a bed of dry, withered, fallen leaves?</l>
    .<l n="d">Words cannot describe how your body has wasted away, and has lost its strength and become wrinkled from long contact* with them.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘In short, my lord, please come with me now to the kingdom of the serpent king and seek </l>
    .<l n="b">To enjoy the happiness that my great devotion will afford you. I beg of you, please accept my offer.</l>
    4010<l n="c">There is no doubt you will be accorded the devotion of all the snakes. Their only wish will be to serve you</l>
    .<l n="d">With food and refreshments, caring for your every wish, joining with you in sexual union.’*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Thus implored Ulupuy, overcome by passion. Pārtha answered lovingly and sweetly:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘O most excellent jewel among women! My dear! By stealth you have captivated my very heart.</l>
    4015<l n="c">Alas, though, the charm of your seductive words cuts me to the quick, cruelly breaking my heart into little pieces,</l>
    .<l n="d">My dear, I must ask you to accept that I must refuse your love, O little sister.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘For I am now bound by the agreement that Nārada has ordained,</l>
    .<l n="b">To live as a <foreign>brāhmācārya</foreign>, holding to chastity. That is the reason I wander here in the Himālaya, seeking solitude.</l>
    4020<l n="c">Only after twelve years will it end and I must wait until that time has elapsed.</l>
    .<l n="d">But how it casts me down, now that I, too, am filled with the desire to enjoy sexual union anew.’*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Thus Arjuna gave her answer, and again the girl spoke:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘O my lord, you are mistaken in taking so much to heart the words of the seer.</l>
    4025<l n="c">I understand what he meant in urging you to comply with his instruction.</l>
    .<l n="d">But surely your solemn and abiding vow was intended only to apply to the Lady Dropadī?</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘With another, how could it be wrong for you to devote yourself to love-making?</l>
    .<l n="b">It would not be adultery if you were to accept my words that speak of seeking sensual pleasure.*</l>
    4030<l n="c">The purpose of assiduously performing the yoga of love is the prosperity of your lineage,</l>
    .<l n="d">So that in practising it and becoming steadfastly absorbed in it, you may achieve the Absolute.’*</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="6">
    4035<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">How could the prince do other than accept her words, seeking to woo him?</l>
    .<l n="b">He tried to curb his doubts then, for her words, asking to be accepted, rang true.</l>
    .<l n="c">And so he sanctioned* them, receiving them favourably, for they were so meet.</l>
    .<l n="d">Moreover, their sweetness was without flaw. ‘No harm* can come of this’, he thought.</l>
    .</p>
    4040<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">And so he decided to follow his desires,* as is the nature of hearts that share love.</l>
    .<l n="b">The prince stood up, made ready, and followed the snake girl.</l>
    .<l n="c">Through a split in the earth’s surface, they took the road to the underworld.</l>
    .<l n="d">But even as they walked on together, without stopping to rest, he took pleasure in the features of the path that she pointed out to him.</l>
    .</p>
    4045<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">They came to her home, a place* where the buildings were of incomparable splendour.</l>
    .<l n="b">The houses were made of gold and all the gateways and fences were of gold and jewels.</l>
    .<l n="c">With its adornments radiating a shimmering glow, it looked like an orb of light, </l>
    .<l n="d">And its dazzling beauty seemed to emanate* from heaven.</l>
    .</p>
    4050<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The world of the gods is made radiant by the sun, that most excellent of brilliant jewels.</l>
    .<l n="b">It is impossible* for it to grow dim there, even when daylight passes and night falls.</l>
    .<l n="c">As for the underworld, when night comes there, the darkness is diminished,</l>
    .<l n="d">For there is constant light from the ever-gleaming crystal and jewels.</l>
    .</p>
    4055<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The snake girl led the prince within,</l>
    .<l n="b">And presented to him the beauty of the place: its golden encircling walls* were indeed perfect.</l>
    .<l n="c">Beautiful women sat there, like scattered jewels loosened from a string. Sweet were their charms,</l>
    .<l n="d">Their side-ways glances arousing desire, their supple bodies the very embodiment of young boughs.</l>
    .</p>
    4060<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">There were some who drew near, ready to receive him, eager to provide all that is due to a guest,</l>
    .<l n="b">Sweetly displaying the fire of their natures in their subtle gestures.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Delightfully bespattered with a dusting of flower-pollen, fragrantly perfumed with musk,</l>
    .<l n="d">Their loveliness was enough to render him speechless, as they seemed to offer their sweetness to his gaze.</l>
    .</p>
    4065<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">There was a pavilion of crystal, its roof a <foreign>madana-</foreign>lotus* of chased gold,</l>
    .<l n="b">With a wonderful arrangement of flower-shaped adornments, formed of brilliant jewels.</l>
    .<l n="c">There was, as well, a couch awaiting there, the visible manifestation of a hymn to love.*</l>
    .<l n="d">Its painted cloths were decorated with clusters of rays, so that it seemed to be the moon’s secret hide-away.*</l>
    .</p>
    4070<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">And so the beautiful girl and the prince mounted the curtained bedstead.</l>
    .<l n="b">Under the ineluctable force of their love, they found harmony at once, their feelings as one.</l>
    .<l n="c">Their union there on that lovely couch was full of joy, the essence of sweet delight,</l>
    .<l n="d">And they seemed the incarnation of the beautiful jasmine, intertwined with the <foreign>gaḍung.</foreign></l>
    .</p>
    4075<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Or their union was perhaps that of flower buds seeking to draw near to the beauty of the river.</l>
    .<l n="b">Clearly the two on the couch were Ratih and Manasija, goddess and god of Love.</l>
    .<l n="c">The entwining of their souls* in sexual congress formed a temple for the innermost expression of the art of love.*</l>
    .<l n="d">Suddenly they could no longer resist tasting the welcome delights* of love-making.</l>
    .</p>
    4080<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Later, when they had been united together in the raptures of love there on the bed,</l>
    .<l n="b">Their sudden delight knew no bounds, their very hearts were touched in their new-found mastery.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Together they came out and sat side by side outside the pavilion,</l>
    .<l n="d">Where their waiting retinue approached them to wait upon them and offer them all that had been prepared.</l>
    .</p>
    4085<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">As they sat outside the crystal pavilion it was as if they had descended from Smara’s heaven.</l>
    .<l n="b">Again and again they partook of the many delicacies of exquisite flavour that stood ready.</l>
    .<l n="c">After they had eaten they again withdrew and together climbed onto the couch,</l>
    .<l n="d">Tirelessly seeking union there on the bed, never wearying of love-making.</l>
    .</p>
    4090<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Blissfully, these enamoured lovers dallied together there on the couch.</l>
    .<l n="b">Then, they wandered together out into the garden, wanting to be alone.</l>
    .<l n="c">Inseparable, they again sought bliss there in the moonlight,</l>
    .<l n="d">Even resting together on a bed of flowers and leaves.</l>
    .</p>
    4095<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">The joyful harbinger of the fourth month, the thunder, brought the promise of soft rain.</l>
    .<l n="b">They wandered here and there, happily stopping from time to time at a hermitage.</l>
    .<l n="c">Moreover on the bank of the river that descended into the ravines near the most inaccessible gullies,</l>
    .<l n="d">There was a spring where they disported together, constant companions, taking with them as provisions only their love and desire.</l>
    .</p>
    4100<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">For a long time they lived together in love, delighting in their passion and love-making,</l>
    .<l n="b">Adept at devoting* themselves to love, ever-willing to surrender to pleasure,</l>
    .<l n="c">Joyfully tasting* the doctrine of love perfected by Dhanañjaya,</l>
    .<l n="d">Striving after union with the deity of love in immaterial form, abandoning themselves to the delights of bliss.*</l>
    .</p>
    4105</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="7">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">For a long time he stayed in the underworld,*</l>
    .<l n="b">And before long an excellent and perfect child was born,</l>
    .<l n="c">Who was later acknowledged as a hero in battle,</l>
    4110<l n="d">And was called Irawan, the renowned.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The prince had not forgotten</l>
    .<l n="b">His mission, bearing it constantly in mind,</l>
    .<l n="c">And so he prepared to set off again,</l>
    4115<l n="d">Gently explaining to his beloved.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a"> He went on his way to other places,</l>
    .<l n="b">And came finally to the Hima mountain.</l>
    .<l n="c">Travelling easily wherever he wished, he made his way</l>
    4120<l n="d">Through the many hills and valleys.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="8">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">He reached a wondrous, rugged mountain range of unearthly beauty,</l>
    4125<l n="b">The renowned Nilaśr̥ngga.* The thick undergrowth of its foothills was difficult to traverse.</l>
    .<l n="c">Its winding gullies were deep, its peak towered over the ravines.</l>
    .<l n="d">Rushing streams welled up from their source and plummeted down into the valleys.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Pure mountain brooks whirled and gushed* from the crevices in the hills,</l>
    4130<l n="b">Shining silver-bright, for all the world like the milk of the earth.</l>
    .<l n="c">Merrily a dove bathed and fluttered its wings, sporting and playing in the water,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Accompanied by its entire family, all of whom had joined in this visit to the holy bathing pool of the seers.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The beauty spots towering high above were a delight to see.</l>
    4135<l n="b">On the hillsides, hermitages nestled at the edges of the ravines.</l>
    .<l n="c">Dotted here and there, in delightful clusters,</l>
    .<l n="d">Were <foreign>puṣpadeha*</foreign> trees, all aflame, like carefully tended fires* that are never allowed to go out.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Enchanting was the sight of all the accomplished, charming anchoresses.</l>
    4140<l n="b">The sweetness they presented to his gaze, as he beheld them, was that of <foreign>campaka</foreign> flowers.</l>
    .<l n="c">With veiled looks,* as is only to be expected, they threatened him with their quivering eyebrows,</l>
    .<l n="d">But their sidelong glances, with hidden smiles, were as sweet as syrup.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">There, in the outer gardens, they gaily gathered vegetables and mushrooms,</l>
    4145<l n="b">As well as <foreign>lalab</foreign>,* which they wrapped in their breast cloths, with never a thought to their [bare] breasts.</l>
    .<l n="c">Their sweet chorus, rising up faintly as they sang there on the side of the ravines, was a joy,</l>
    .<l n="d">As the frogs answered in soft counterpoint from the gullies.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">In the forest hermitage, love-smitten, they offered their beauty to the seers.*</l>
    4150<l n="b">Some gathered flowers and bunches of grass which they then arranged, carefully protecting them from their [sharp] nails;</l>
    .<l n="c">Others walked carefully, gracefully into the pond to scoop up water,</l>
    .<l n="d">And as he watched them closely and they feigned displeasure, they seemed just as sweet as heavenly nymphs.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">From above, the water [of the pond] lapped at the waters of the sea lying below.</l>
    4155<l n="b">A fountain spouted up from a fissure, its water thrown up in the centre.</l>
    .<l n="c">The misty, glistening spray, lit by the sun’s rays, formed a rainbow,</l>
    .<l n="d">With jets of water that looked like a line of slithering snakes flying through the air.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The buds of the woodland trees sighed with longing for the fine river mist.</l>
    4160<l n="b">And seemed to draw near its beauty humbly, to ask that they might be placed in a hair-knot.</l>
    .<l n="c">As Dhanañjaya came without warning on the delights of the hermitage,</l>
    .<l n="d">The sound of the <foreign>kuwong</foreign> seemed to call them to come forward now that the prince had arrived.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    4165<div type="canto" n="9">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Completely absorbed, the noble Phalguṇa gazed with delight upon</l>
    .<l n="b">The scenic beauty of that mountain hermitage as it rose into view,</l>
    .<l n="c">And because he felt so weary, now that the sun’s heat had utterly sapped his strength,</l>
    .<l n="d">In the end he did not hurry past at all, so tired was he.</l>
    4170</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">At times the path climbed upwards and he could look with delight, as far as the horizon.</l>
    .<l n="b">The beauty was enhanced by the lovely birds on their homeward journey.</l>
    .<l n="c">Gracefully flying in formation, they faded from sight,</l>
    .<l n="d">While with breathtaking beauty, the hills seemed to flash.</l>
    4175</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The delightful path went step-by-step downwards along the side of the deep ravine.</l>
    .<l n="b">The undergrowth came right* to the ledge, hidden* beneath the overhanging creepers.</l>
    .<l n="c">By leaning over a long way, he could see the shoots of the <foreign>galing</foreign> creeper* far down in the gully,</l>
    .<l n="d">Some were entwined around the betel trees, others stood tall and straight.*</l>
    4180</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The new leaves of the <foreign>walik-aḍəp</foreign> on the outskirts of the hermitage, flickered.</l>
    .<l n="b">Wild banana leaves hung limply as if deprived of strength,</l>
    .<l n="c">Then, as the wind caught them, stood straight out like pennants,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Alternating with the fluttering shoots of the <foreign>anḍuru</foreign>* beckoning constantly.</l>
    4185</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Just then, the clear cry of the barking deer rang out. How sweet its gaze*</l>
    .<l n="b">As it came to rest on the merry monkeys bustling about in the trees.</l>
    .<l n="c">Some were lazily nibbling the many fruits, chattering the while.</l>
    .<l n="d">Others, the long-tailed monkeys, rested, just squatting in the branches, oblivious to everything.</l>
    4190</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">It would take too long to describe* this scene. Soon after, he came to a hermitage.</l>
    .<l n="b">The trees all shimmered as if to welcome him.</l>
    .<l n="c">Coquettishly they let their flowers fall to the ground like a rain of jewels,</l>
    .<l n="d">Releasing their fragrant perfume without pause as they lay scattered there, enchantingly.</l>
    4195</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Time passed and in the quiet of evening the sun took its course.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Its rays lost their splendour as dusk fell.</l>
    .<l n="c">As if dyed crimson-red, the heavens shone brightly,</l>
    .<l n="d">Wisps of cloud spattered here and there like drops of blood.</l>
    4200</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The magnificent design of that sacred hermitage enhanced the beauty even more.</l>
    .<l n="b">It was shrouded in webs of cloud that settled over all,</l>
    .<l n="c">And were absorbed* into the smoke of the sacrificial fires of the seers,</l>
    .<l n="d">In evidence that impurity and darkness of mind had been destroyed, burnt up in the fire.</l>
    4205</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The fragrance of the oblations within wafted out and spread far and wide.</l>
    .<l n="b">Their perfumes, mingling together with the scent of aromatic smoke from the lamps, covered everything.</l>
    .<l n="c">Cymbals clashed, bells tinkled together in unison</l>
    .<l n="d">With the recitation of prayers - all served to captivate his heart and bring him peace.</l>
    4210</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Birds billed and cooed all the while as they roosted in the hermitage,</l>
    .<l n="b">In tumultuous discourse, ever discussing and interpreting the sacred syllables,</l>
    .<l n="c">To the delightful accompaniment of the bees whose voices could be heard in the fragrant garlands,*</l>
    .<l n="d">As if expert in gracefully leading the gentle, mellifluous singing.</l>
    4215</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">So many delights did the prince see in the hermitage,</l>
    .<l n="b">And so astonished and enraptured was he, that his weariness vanished.</l>
    .<l n="c">Lost in thought, he observed closely, resting on a flat, broad rock</l>
    .<l n="d">And determined, instead, to spend the night in the hermitage.</l>
    4220</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="10">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">But let us now turn our attention to the seers who all came quickly to welcome their guest.</l>
    .<l n="b">All the anchoresses who dwelt in the hermitage and who had been dressing themselves came forth,</l>
    4225<l n="c">Rushing out, leaving behind their clothing of bark cloth, unable to wait.</l>
    .<l n="d">So full of joy were they to see a man of such beauty that they were quite overwhelmed.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">They ran toward the prince who, as if summoned by the power of their meditation,* sat there</l>
    .<l n="b">Charmingly, underneath an <foreign>aśoka</foreign> tree, holding on his lap a garland of flowers.</l>
    4230<l n="c">The ascetics gazed at him open-mouthed,* for his appearance so far surpassed all others in excellence,</l>
    .<l n="d">That they could only think that he was the God of Love Kāma, the sight of him rendering them speechless.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The nuns too were so dazed that they seemed to have lost their senses,</l>
    .<l n="b">Displaying their thoughts and longings as if they were quite incapable of hiding the desire in their eyes.</l>
    4235<l n="c">The seers greeted him: ‘Fortunate are we who dwell in this hermitage!</l>
    .<l n="d">By your arrival, O Prince, we have now reaped the rewards of those* who have achieved indifference to the world.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘What is it you seek in wandering these forested regions, O Prince?</l>
    .<l n="b">It is as if you are the origin* of all that is excellent, and will bring to an end the barren state of us who dwell in this forest.</l>
    4240<l n="c">Through steadfast meditation, the felicity of our ascetic practices has been restored,</l>
    .<l n="d">And now, by your kind favour, we will go on to attain our goals.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Thus said the great sages and the prince told the holy men,</l>
    .<l n="b">Serenely, of the true reason he had come to the holy bathing place,</l>
    4245<l n="c">Relating also the tale of his deeds in the underworld.</l>
    .<l n="d">Happy were the seers to hear [his story] which so heartened them.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">At last, the ascetics escorted the prince into the hermitage.</l>
    .<l n="b">On his arrival they treated him with great care and attention,</l>
    4250<l n="c">Providing him with water for washing his face and feet, as well as roots, fruits and efficacious herbs and potions.</l>
    .<l n="d">Dhanañjaya was delighted, his heart captivated by the seers.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">During the time the prince spent in the hermitage,</l>
    .<l n="b">Many ascetics came to him,* longing to draw near him.</l>
    4255<l n="c">He wandered in the hermitage and was welcomed wherever he went by great sages,</l>
    .<l n="d">Bringing joy to the holy men of these communities.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">For a long time he sojourned with the seers,</l>
    .<l n="b">As if he had no other thought in his mind* but the constant well-being of others.</l>
    4260<l n="c">At last he begged leave to depart from the holy abbot,</l>
    .<l n="d">Who, pleased to consent, embraced the prince:</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘O Sir, place of refuge of the defenceless, who cares for the welfare of religious communities throughout the kingdom!</l>
    .<l n="b">We have been able to share in the joy of one such as you, who is endowed with true excellence, my lord.</l>
    4265<l n="c">Clearly, you are a great man in choosing to dwell in the mountains.</l>
    .<l n="d">May you show compassion and continue to travel the path of virtue* as the support of righteousness!’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Thus said the priestly sage. The prince then set off,</l>
    .<l n="b">Making his way through the groves of the hermitage towards the rolling hills.</l>
    4270<l n="c">Devoted as he was to spiritual purity, he bathed there in the river and was cleansed of all impurities.</l>
    .<l n="d">He then set off for another realm, where too he was received with joy.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">For there was a most excellent king, famed throughout the land for his meritorious deeds and exceptional qualities,</l>
    .<l n="b">Who reigned in Mayūra, the marvellous capital of his kingdom.</l>
    4275<l n="c">The name of Citradahana was truly renowned as world-protector,</l>
    .<l n="d">He was ever the benefactor of those without recourse, never seeking victory when he saw others fail.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="11">
    4280<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">King Citradahana had a daughter of such flawless beauty,</l>
    .<l n="b">It seemed the Goddess of Beauty had taken residence in her body.</l>
    .<l n="c">The very perfume of the flowers seemed diminished as they held their breath in awe of her, </l>
    .<l n="d">And therefore the princess was known as Citragandhā, ‘The Fragrant One.’</l>
    .</p>
    4285<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">But it was well-known that the king’s mind was indeed troubled, </l>
    .<l n="b">His heart dwelled only on his plight.</l>
    .<l n="c">For he knew there was a danger he would have no one to succeed him in the future,</l>
    .<l n="d">And was full of concern for the protection of his realm.</l>
    .</p>
    4290<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The king thought constantly of his coming need for a son-in-law,</l>
    .<l n="b">And thus he sought a perfect man of good character,</l>
    .<l n="c">That he might beget an heir who would succeed to the throne and rule the land,</l>
    .<l n="d">But his heart knew only despair as he reflected on his desire.</l>
    .</p>
    4295<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">For what worthy man would really allow such a thing,</l>
    .<l n="b">And be willing to marry without force or command?*</l>
    .<l n="c">‘To act in such a way would certainly be wrong’, he thought, ‘truly base conduct.</l>
    .<l n="d">It is not the proper way of upright men to embark on an evil course.*</l>
    .</p>
    4300<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘For girls ripe for marriage, it should be like this:</l>
    .<l n="b">A flower at the peak of beauty attracts the bee itself </l>
    .<l n="c">And so it is fitting that she should be carried off by force to find satisfaction.</l>
    .<l n="d">Such is the analogy for young people who obtain their partners without coercion.’</l>
    .</p>
    4305<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Thus the king grieved, with nothing to solace his heart,</l>
    .<l n="b">He forgot everything but his fervent longing, finding it impossible to conquer* his wandering thoughts.</l>
    .<l n="c">His advisors too, seemed helpless,</l>
    .<l n="d">‘Such has never happened before’ they thought, every one of them moaning with distress.</l>
    .</p>
    4310<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">But in the web of existence, two forces ebb and flow -</l>
    .<l n="b">Good and evil - both are encountered, both are ever-present,</l>
    .<l n="c">In equal measure, always part of the life of every creature.</l>
    .<l n="d">Rich and poor, coarse and fine, there is none who is not held in their thrall.*</l>
    .</p>
    4315<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Those who forget the meaning of religion and neglect the eternal worship of Śiwa,</l>
    .<l n="b">Surely will encounter difficulties in their life and will never reach liberation.</l>
    .<l n="c">But the King of Mayūra was faithful in his religious observances and always adhered firmly to them.</l>
    .<l n="d">He, who had known joy, now found it was sorrow that drew near and trailed him.</l>
    .</p>
    4320<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">So he hid in his heart the great burden of his sorrow,</l>
    .<l n="b">And always allowed himself to be amused and seemingly untroubled.</l>
    .<l n="c">He diverted himself on the shore and in forest hermitages,</l>
    .<l n="d">Again and again, as a means of distracting himself from his misery.</l>
    .</p>
    4325<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">For a long time, the king had been in torment, filled with longing,</l>
    .<l n="b">Guided by the dictates of his heart, thinking only of the resolution of his dilemma,</l>
    .<l n="c">And now the intervention of the gods had brought about the arrival of Pārtha,</l>
    .<l n="d">Who would clearly dispel the king’s misery.</l>
    .</p>
    4330<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">For the beauty of the most excellent princess was so renowned</l>
    .<l n="b">That even the loveliness of the mountains trembled, their power to entrance vanquished.</l>
    .<l n="c">The charm of poems seemed to peter out, their beauty just floating away,</l>
    .<l n="d">And so, borne along by what he had heard, the prince came there.</l>
    .</p>
    4335<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">It was heard far and wide that Arjuna, the excellent son of Pāṇḍu, was visiting the king.</l>
    .<l n="b">How delighted he was to welcome this guest.</l>
    .<l n="c">His officials dared to place all their hopes in him,</l>
    .<l n="d">Like flower buds taking sustenance* from the arrival of the gentle rain from the clouds.</l>
    .</p>
    4340<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">All at once the country resembled a mighty ocean.</l>
    .<l n="b">It shook with the thundering of the people as they poured forth from the palace.</l>
    .<l n="c">The prince was like the full moon shining down upon them</l>
    .<l n="d">And so, beset by love-pangs, they whispered to each other, sighing continually.</l>
    .</p>
    4345<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">They stared and stared at the extraordinary beauty of the prince.</l>
    .<l n="b">He encompassed the arrival of the God of Love, the season of flowers and the sweetness of the season of honey at once.</l>
    .<l n="c">Moreover he was irresistible, mighty, splendid and virtuous in battle.</l>
    .<l n="d">And thus all they could talk of was this handsome prince.</l>
    .</p>
    4350<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">And so, the king approached the prince,</l>
    .<l n="b">His countenance sweet with welcome, his every gesture friendly.</l>
    .<l n="c">His kind and warm greeting went straight to the heart of the newly-arrived guest:</l>
    .<l n="d">‘Great is our good fortune that you have come here, my son.</l>
    .</p>
    4355<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">‘We were like withered grass and trees that have given up hope, </l>
    .<l n="b">Denied access to rain, terrible indeed was our longing, weary were we with craving,</l>
    .<l n="c">Our restlessness plumbing the very depths. But now, suddenly, inexplicably, we have burst into bud.</l>
    .<l n="d">For we think, you have brought the mercy of god Suranatha within our reach.</l>
    .</p>
    4360<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">‘This realm has been so arid and fruitless,</l>
    .<l n="b">As if through its own misdeeds it has become barren and lustreless.</l>
    .<l n="c">It may now come to know good fortune,</l>
    .<l n="d">For your virtue and excellence will bring it prosperity.’</l>
    .</p>
    4365<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">These were the king’s happy words. The prince replied:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘Indeed no, O King! You go too far in praising me thus.</l>
    .<l n="c">Your wisdom is all-surpassing. You are pure, concerned for the good of others, your power is over-reaching.</l>
    .<l n="d">And therefore, Your Majesty, I pay homage to you, you who makes my heart soar.’*</l>
    .</p>
    4370<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">And he then asked for the hand of the excellent princess.</l>
    .<l n="b">The king of Mayūra was willing to grant his request:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘My dear boy, take my beloved daughter to serve you as your wife. You may be her husband.</l>
    .<l n="d">May you know joy! But there is a promise I must exact from you.</l>
    .</p>
    4375<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">‘Formerly Mayūra was an excellent realm, as you have no doubt heard.</l>
    .<l n="b">Its king, my own forefather, was Prabhākara.</l>
    .<l n="c">For a very long time he reigned,* but had no royal heir,</l>
    .<l n="d">And so, desirous of a child, he withdrew to perform austerities.</l>
    .</p>
    4380<p rend="stanza" n="21"><l n="a">‘When he saw how steadfast was the king, God Iśwara was merciful, </l>
    .<l n="b">And granted to him the boon of a child, </l>
    .<l n="c">And one, - and only one, - to each of his descendants too, </l>
    .<l n="d">So that, ever after, his line would reign in this kingdom.</l>
    .</p>
    4385</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="12">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘The cause of the difficulties we now suffer and which bring us such sorrow,</l>
    .<l n="b">Is that the deeds of his former life have come to nothing and have brought only bewilderment,</l>
    .<l n="c">For I am left with a child, a most beautiful daughter,</l>
    4390<l n="d">Who obviously cannot continue to safeguard the weal of my subjects.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘Look kindly on my plea, O Prince. From you I hope for compassion.</l>
    .<l n="b">My request is for a male child,</l>
    .<l n="c">A child whose destiny it would be to be my heir,</l>
    4395<l n="d">And be enthroned in this land. This is the bride-price.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Thus he spoke. The prince, without hesitation,</l>
    .<l n="b">Vowed that any child of the princess, </l>
    .<l n="c">Any fine son, would succeed to the throne.</l>
    4400<l n="d">With this pledge, the agreement they had deliberated was sealed.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The king then gave directions* to all the palace officials,</l>
    .<l n="b">For the betrothal of the princess to Arjuna.</l>
    .<l n="c">The army were delighted to hear of it, giving their full support,</l>
    4405<l n="d">For it is in the nature of those who serve to be loyal in this way.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">At once, they attended to all that would be required for the celebration of love.</l>
    .<l n="b">Preparing everything, bringing it all to the bed-chamber.</l>
    .<l n="c">Laying out for them perfectly, without delay,</l>
    4410<l n="d">All the ritual requisites, of unequalled splendour, arranged in full measure.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The ladies of the palace, hearing [the news], took pleasure</l>
    .<l n="b">In preparing and setting out the gifts of homage attractively.</l>
    .<l n="c">Others attended to the ornaments but all were equally delighted to welcome their guest,</l>
    4415<l n="d">Their hearts beating wildly with pleasure* as they pictured him in their minds.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">A beautiful pavilion* had been set ready for his use.</l>
    .<l n="b">It was unequalled in its true magnificence,</l>
    .<l n="c">Of unparalleled design, ringed by a moat,</l>
    4420<l n="d">As splendid as the Hima mountain.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">This was the place they had prepared for Dhanañjaya.</l>
    .<l n="b">Many delicious dishes were to be made and offered to him.</l>
    .<l n="c">Ready to meet his every wish, some led the singing,</l>
    4425<l n="d">Accompanying their melody with drums and the sweet music of the <foreign>kətur</foreign>.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">As the sun set, the king withdrew,</l>
    .<l n="b">His heart no longer beset by constant worry.</l>
    .<l n="c">Because of the strength of his feelings towards Dhanañjaya,</l>
    4430<l n="d">His joy was reflected in his radiant countenance.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="13">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The king went to his quarters and made for the queen’s apartment within,</l>
    4435<l n="b">Where his arrival was welcomed with smiles and he was ushered in with sweet glances.</l>
    .<l n="c">He informed the queen of what he had done </l>
    .<l n="d">And the reason for his plan to marry off their daughter.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The queen made no objection to the marriage of the princess.</l>
    4440<l n="b">The palace ladies were also all highly delighted, some even felt burgeoning desire,</l>
    .<l n="c">Thinking: ‘Indeed the prince is fitting to hold power over our princess.’</l>
    .<l n="d">But let us not describe that. The king then went to the princess.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">As soon as she knew of the king’s visit, the princess</l>
    4445<l n="b">Became very agitated, anxious to hear what he had in mind.</l>
    .<l n="c">The king’s approach filled her with an anxiety that she tried to restrain,</l>
    .<l n="d">Fighting back her tears, even as she came forward to greet him as he entered.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Her sorrow, so obviously hidden, filled the hearts of the palace women with pity.</l>
    4450<l n="b">Many of her young attendants were skilful at interpreting the outward signs of her inner feelings</l>
    .<l n="c">And so they drew near to sit beside her, like a profusion of jasmine flowers to behold,</l>
    .<l n="d">But the princess so outstripped their charms, that even at first sight* she seemed like the moon.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">As she made her obeisance, her slender arms were like bending boughs.</l>
    4455<l n="b">Her waist and limbs were so supple that they seemed a collection of unsharpened <foreign>kris.</foreign>*</l>
    .<l n="c">Even more beautiful was the sight of her body, aglow* in the light of the lamps.</l>
    .<l n="d">Her face grew pale like the waning moon, as she was suddenly overcome with fear.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Then the king, his queen beside him,* addressed the princess:</l>
    4460<l n="b">‘O my child, there is none but you to whom we can turn to perform this favour for us.</l>
    .<l n="c">You alone can fulfil it and ensure our well-being, O princess,</l>
    .<l n="d">If only you will show compassion and be the instrument through which we may reach heaven.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘O my darling jewel, truly* we ask much of you.</l>
    4465<l n="b">Please accept the inevitability of our words. How could we possibly deny* the love we have for you, my daughter?</l>
    .<l n="c">But now your body is ripe, the proper place to bring* a husband without delay,</l>
    .<l n="d">And so Dhanañjaya is to be your husband, for he is a fitting match for you’.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus said the king. As for the princess, she made no reply.</l>
    4470<l n="b">Despairingly she held back her tears, her heart crushed, not knowing what to do.</l>
    .<l n="c">She feared to disappoint the king by disobeying his command,</l>
    .<l n="d">So she merely sighed endlessly as she listened to her father and mother.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The queen spoke next: ‘My child you must heed the king,</l>
    4475<l n="b">As you know we have only you, my dear, to uphold our honour.</l>
    .<l n="c">You will perform a great service for our lineage, if you but give life to a male grandchild,* </l>
    .<l n="d">Who will reign here in Mayūra, and thus your marriage settlement* will become the source of our kingdom’s strength.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘Come! Accept this! Do not suppose that the king would neglect his duty as ruler.</l>
    4480<l n="b">He who has a child or wife wishes only to dispel their troubles.</l>
    .<l n="c">Unwise is he who is bound by the love of a child, for it will lead him to shame.</l>
    .<l n="d">His concern is that they are not held subject* by the fortunes and misfortunes that are encountered in this world.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Having spoken thus the king [and queen] retired and the princess was left alone.</l>
    4485<l n="b">So distraught was she as her maids led her away, that she felt suddenly faint, and swayed, burdened by sorrow.</l>
    .<l n="c">She reached the sanctuary of the bower of creepers, bewailing the fate of maidens* who are to wed.</l>
    .<l n="d">Her tears flowed unabated, as her maids tried to soothe her with words of comfort.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    4490<div type="canto" n="14">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">All the ladies of the court were dazed and wandered restlessly about, lost in dreams, becoming weak with longing,</l>
    .<l n="b">Carried away by desire, overwhelmed with rapture, rendered powerless by the prince’s sweet charms that so wounded them.</l>
    .<l n="c">Feverish, burning with secret desires, overcome with the confusion of unfulfilled love, there in the moonlight that streamed in,</l>
    .<l n="d">Falling silent now he, who was the very embodiment of love, had come there riding upon the moon.*</l>
    4495</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">One girl, sitting there forlornly on the floor with her hair unbound, swooning, was pitiful in her dejection,</l>
    .<l n="b">Writing of her desire on a lovely <foreign>sumanasa</foreign> flower, turning her longing to letters,</l>
    .<l n="c">As she whispered to her serving girl, telling of the pain of her love-sickness,</l>
    .<l n="d">Heart-brokenly giving voice to her sorrow in a charming lament.</l>
    4500</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Another, her <foreign>kain</foreign> in disarray,* lay on the lap of her attendant, her great ardour unabated,</l>
    .<l n="b">Confused, mad with longing for a response to the rapturous delight of blissful lovers,</l>
    .<l n="c">Who are happy just to wander along the sea-shore, lost in the composition of love-poems,</l>
    .<l n="d">Undaunted even when brought to a stop by the rising tide, content, though there is no shelter for the night.</l>
    4505</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Yet another jewel among women, her charms at their peak like a flower in bud,</l>
    .<l n="b">Mournfully lost in reverie, weighed down by her feelings of longing and sadness, was being gently massaged, underneath an <foreign>aśoka</foreign> tree.</l>
    .<l n="c">Her maid, assiduously devoted to her every need, attended her with words of comfort,</l>
    .<l n="d">But knew full well that only in union with the prince could she find comfort for her sorrow:</l>
    4510</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘How can a profusion of flower-buds* burst open, if they must risk spoiling their beauty?</l>
    .<l n="b">They will wither completely if the fourth month does not come to bring its gentle rain, so that they might unfold.</l>
    .<l n="c">Their new leaves are to no avail, the spiteful wind seems only to tease them mercilessly, tossing them to and fro,</l>
    .<l n="d">So that they want only to dive into those cruel clouds so long awaited, bowed down with longing.</l>
    4515</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Oh what other outcome could there be but that their beautiful petals*would die?</l>
    .<l n="b">The fragrance of the <foreign>asana</foreign>, the jasmine, the <foreign>suraga</foreign>, even the luxuriant* <foreign>nagapuṣpa,</foreign> would be pointless</l>
    .<l n="c">If the bees shunned them and no longer desired to caress them,</l>
    .<l n="d">Just as the splendour of the moon would cease if the love-sick <foreign>cucur</foreign> bird abandoned it.</l>
    4520</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘My dearest mistress, you who are sister to the beauty of the fourth month,</l>
    .<l n="b">I know the meaning of your words, you are the pale* <foreign>aśoka</foreign> in bud.</l>
    .<l n="c">Oh alas! How it awakens my pity, dear one, to see your sweet charms so enfeebled.</l>
    .<l n="d">Indeed yours is the sad plight of a flower that withers the moment it is taken from a fragrant hair-knot.</l>
    4525</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘O maiden, look here, I, your servant, my jewel, will go to the prince.</l>
    .<l n="b">I will take this lovely petal as a token of your homage to him, the god of the love-sick.</l>
    .<l n="c">When he beholds your sweetness, how could he not be won over and long fervently for the ocean of honey,</l>
    .<l n="d">So that only in being engulfed in its centre, would he find respite for his passionate longing.’</l>
    4530</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="15">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">It would take too long to tell of the thoughts of these women, whose hearts ached</l>
    .<l n="b">With the passion and bewilderment that engulfed them.</l>
    4535<l n="c">They tossed restlessly, greatly distressed,</l>
    .<l n="d">Confused, carried away by desires that, though they tried to ward them off, overwhelmed them so.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">But the princess was not thus affected.</l>
    .<l n="b">She was listless and dispirited, and paid no heed to her surroundings.</l>
    4540<l n="c">Her attendants and maids untiringly caressed her,</l>
    .<l n="d">Seeking words to bring her comfort.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Her pitiful moans became more acute,</l>
    .<l n="b">For her mind was in turmoil, preoccupied.</l>
    4545<l n="c">Tormented and brooding, she was unable to sleep, </l>
    .<l n="d">As is the way of young girls.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The king’s decision, commanding her</l>
    .<l n="b">To be married now without delay,</l>
    4550<l n="c">Was both the cause of her suffering</l>
    .<l n="d">And the reason for her deep bewilderment.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">She could hear the music of <foreign>geṇḍing</foreign> and drums outside,</l>
    .<l n="b">In merry, sweet accompaniment to the singing.</l>
    4555<l n="c">The lovely strains of the <foreign>curing</foreign> cymbals of the <foreign>piḍuḍukan</foreign> ceremony,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Rang out the whole night long to torment her.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">But enough of that. Night soon passed,</l>
    .<l n="b">And the waning moon went off to hide away.</l>
    4560<l n="c">The seventh hour* rang out, </l>
    .<l n="d">As if inviting daylight to hasten there.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="16">
    4565<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">When every kind of ceremonial requisite had been prepared and laid ready,</l>
    .<l n="b">The populace entered and assembled in the outer courtyard.</l>
    .<l n="c">At daybreak, the sun shone bright and clear, radiating its brilliance everywhere.</l>
    .<l n="d">The city gleamed brightly, crimson-red, and the <foreign>gəṇḍing</foreign> resounded merrily.</l>
    .</p>
    4570<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">There in the outer hall, the king received homage,</l>
    .<l n="b">The exuberance of the court ever-increasing, like the rising ocean.</l>
    .<l n="c">Great throngs of people spread everywhere, scurrying busily about, </l>
    .<l n="d">The <foreign>saragi</foreign> gongs* crashing in joyful competition, like waves breaking.</l>
    .</p>
    4575<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Some people were merrily eating and drinking together, in full measure,</l>
    .<l n="b">The whole day spent happily in each other’s company, completely unrestrained, everything without fault.</l>
    .<l n="c">But let us tell now of the princess, in the pavilion, undergoing the <foreign>piḍuḍukan</foreign> ceremony.</l>
    .<l n="d">Her sweet charms rivalled those of Ratih, Goddess of Love, as she was adorned.*</l>
    .</p>
    4580<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">As she was assiduously attended by those officiating* in the inner chamber</l>
    .<l n="b">And by those who adorned her in splendour, the maiden became more and more dejected,</l>
    .<l n="c">So upset at the king’s apparent disregard of her,</l>
    .<l n="d">That she could take no pleasure in the beauty of the decorations with which they adorned her.</l>
    .</p>
    4585<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Although she was truly worthy to vanquish the beauty of the wondrous fourth month,</l>
    .<l n="b">Her sorrow made her as lifeless as a withered flower.</l>
    .<l n="c">The sun began to go down as if to hasten the wedding-night,</l>
    .<l n="d">While the awesome rumble of the thunder, with its soft and quavering sound, seemed a prelude to love-making.</l>
    .</p>
    4590<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Inside that beautiful pavilion the noble princess was attended.</l>
    .<l n="b">Moreover, because all the most beautiful adornments had been reserved for it,</l>
    .<l n="c">The <foreign>pamiḍuḍukan</foreign> pavilion was breath-takingingly lovely, quite enchanting.*</l>
    .<l n="d">While her maid servants, all thoroughly accomplished in the arts of beauty, were like heavenly nymphs.</l>
    .</p>
    4595<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">So great were her charms that she was like an ornamented painting of a goddess,</l>
    .<l n="b">Such an incomparable and excellent girl was she, the supreme jewel of the palace.</l>
    .<l n="c">The unending molten stream of the goddess of nectar would yield before her, infatuated,</l>
    .<l n="d">By her sweetness and would be reduced to confusion to see her own beauty take on visible form.</l>
    .</p>
    4600<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The setting sun had sent its rays to keep watch over her painted lips.</l>
    .<l n="b">Clearly, rain-filled* clouds were in her hair-knot.</l>
    .<l n="c">Darting swallows flying about seemed to have become one with her frowning brows,</l>
    .<l n="d">And the flickering lightning had lost its brightness, in service to her feet.</l>
    .</p>
    4605<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Then the melodic sound of the prayers and rituals became louder,</l>
    .<l n="b">Its charm enhanced by the soft murmuring of those gathered in the outer court.</l>
    .<l n="c">The accompaniment of the lovely <foreign>gəṇḍing</foreign> and <foreign>curing</foreign>* aroused feelings of longing,</l>
    .<l n="d">Their musical offering bringing to mind the tossing of the beautiful ocean.</l>
    .</p>
    4610<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">At sunset, the clouds shone like red silk.</l>
    .<l n="b">At the fifth hour the enchanting moon goddess rose and shone brightly.</l>
    .<l n="c">But, disheartened that this true incarnation of beauty mocked her </l>
    .<l n="d">And worsted her, she became pale and waited there, hidden behind the dark clouds that cast shadows across her [face].</l>
    .</p>
    4615<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">The princess’s ornaments were so decoratively arranged by those waiting upon her</l>
    .<l n="b">That it seemed as if the beauty of the dawn was shamed and took leave of her charms.</l>
    .<l n="c">Indeed, all the sentiments of delight in a love-poem or the subtle allusions in an allegory*</l>
    .<l n="d">Were to be found in her sweetness and, if but whispered, would invoke feelings of love.</l>
    .</p>
    4620<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">We will say no more of the princess but tell instead of the prince.*</l>
    .<l n="b">He was showered with all requisites and due ceremonies </l>
    .<l n="c">By the king,* who now arranged the wedding.</l>
    .<l n="d">In due time, the bridal couple withdrew. We will now tell of them.</l>
    .</p>
    4625<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">They went up together into the beautiful bed-chamber.</l>
    .<l n="b">That the rites of marriage* would be delightful, was plain for all to see in [the prince’s] desire.</l>
    .<l n="c">It was as if he had been overwhelmed with the unconstrained delight that is treasured on a delicately-made writing board</l>
    .<l n="d">And the beautiful princess was clearly the wondrousness of gentle rain.*</l>
    .</p>
    4630<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">As the princess mounted the bedstead,</l>
    .<l n="b">Her heart was filled with dread and disquiet. Despondently she was led in.</l>
    .<l n="c">She was truly afraid because of the sorrow that now visited her,</l>
    .<l n="d">And she could find no solace, as she felt an unremitting sadness sweep over her.</l>
    .</p>
    4635<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">As they sat there together, all who saw them thought them delightful:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘Our princess is the image of a young banana leaf newly unfolding.</l>
    .<l n="c">The prince is like a profusion of <foreign>jangga</foreign> vine, unrestrainedly caressing her.’</l>
    .<l n="d">Thus they thought, full of longing, their wounded hearts captivated.</l>
    .</p>
    4640</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="17">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">So alluring and beautiful was the scene, with moonlight enhancing the beauty</l>
    .<l n="b">Of the bright, glowing pavilion, it was truly without equal.</l>
    .<l n="c">The lustrous radiance of the gold ridge-pole was augmented by jewels,</l>
    4645<l n="d">And the light of the moon grew pale when irradiated by their gleam, sparkling in all directions.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The splendid draperies were like those used to curtain a grotto of love.</l>
    .<l n="b">The sun-red glowing horizon seemed to have moved there.</l>
    .<l n="c">Moreover the couch within the house of creepers was spread with softest silks.*</l>
    4650<l n="d">Camphor and unguent gave forth their fragrance, diffusing their scent and perfumes overall.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The prince had already been enthroned* on the couch,</l>
    .<l n="b">And had taken the girl on his lap, where she lay deprived of strength, all atremble.</l>
    .<l n="c">When they were left alone there, he was just like a bee caressing a budding flower.</l>
    4655<l n="d">He became more and more like an intoxicated <foreign>taḍaharṣa</foreign> bird paying homage to the moon, overwhelmed by longing.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Bewildered and wan, the beautiful girl grew ever more afraid, and sighed,</l>
    .<l n="b">Bending gracefully aside when he tried to seize her waist, moving away, warding him off.</l>
    .<l n="c">Overwhelming sadness totally crushed her heart into little pieces,</l>
    4660<l n="d">And tears of honey suddenly welled up in her eyes, as she arched her brows threateningly.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">His heart beating wildly, the prince became more and more passionate.</l>
    .<l n="b">Clearly he was the embodiment of honey, blended with sweetest syrup,</l>
    .<l n="c">Akin to the thunder of the fourth month, that lightens the suffering of those overcome by the pains of love.</l>
    4665<l n="d">And his words, droplets of sweet delight, were the essence of love:</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘O maiden! Queen of the beauty of <foreign>asanas</foreign>! Flower of the whole kingdom!</l>
    .<l n="b">You are my final destination, the very cause of my love-sick passions.</l>
    .<l n="c">All joy and desire embodied in an incomparably wrought jewel are you,</l>
    4670<l n="d">The fulfilment of a dream, [a gift] from the God of Love, magically appearing.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘Therefore you have been accorded first place* by all beautiful women.</l>
    .<l n="b">Have pity on me, the one whose heart has striven to resist the dictates of the God of Love.</l>
    .<l n="c">Clearly it is because of my love-sick heart that I reach for you, seeking you out.</l>
    4675<l n="d">And so I have come humbly to seek refuge with you, here in the bed-chamber.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus he spoke. But the maiden he sought to woo averted her face, weeping.</l>
    .<l n="b">Her body, lithe as a tendril, seemed to wilt, as she sighed plaintively.</l>
    .<l n="c">The prince’s passion was so intense,* so uncontrolled, that she grew very apprehensive</l>
    4680<l n="d">As his intent gaze sought to reveal her secret places.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘O my darling, why do you treat my troubles so lightly as I seek your favour?</l>
    .<l n="b">Even though you stab me with your eyebrows, how could that be reason enough for me to go away and abandon myself to longing?</l>
    .<l n="c">I would think myself fortunate if I could but be pierced by your beautiful glances. What would I care if I were cut to pieces?</l>
    4685<l n="d">My darling, my only hope is that I, who so desire you, might now receive the gift of your love.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">The object of his love-struck worship, weary of resisting, sank down, weeping,</l>
    .<l n="b">Helplessly striking at him with her hands as if she would blunt her nails.</l>
    .<l n="c">As he seized her waist-band, it suddenly came loose from her fragrant, slender waist.</l>
    4690<l n="d">And though it seemed she would die as he threatened her thus, he ignored her fear and took possession of her.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Intent on his purpose, unable to restrain his mounting excitement, </l>
    .<l n="b">The prince abandoned himself to the overwhelming force of his boundless desire, quite without mercy.</l>
    .<l n="c">For it so assailed him that, in the end, he ravished* the beautiful princess,</l>
    4695<l n="d">Pressing down* upon her trembling breasts, now laid bare, filling her with fear and aversion.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="18">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">After being thus deflowered, the weary maiden was completely devastated,</l>
    4700<l n="b">Like a pale leaf that has just withered away.</l>
    .<l n="c">Gasping for breath, deprived of all strength, she rose and stumbling to the foot of the couch, sank down there,</l>
    .<l n="d">Her embroidered, fragrant robe stained with blood, glistening wet.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Aghast, she readjusted her clothing</l>
    4705<l n="b">For fear of again being forced to make love.</l>
    .<l n="c">She went dejectedly from the fragrant boudoir,</l>
    .<l n="d">A sudden frown on her face at seeing the blood trickling to her feet.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Her maids, taken by surprise as she came out, greeted her:</l>
    4710<l n="b">‘Dear mistress, pay no attention to your pain, my dear.</l>
    .<l n="c">Why it is just like taking betel – the first time, it is hot to the lips,</l>
    .<l n="d">But there is no doubt that the next time it, instead, becomes* delightful’.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">And so the princess was urged to return at once,</l>
    4715<l n="b">With coaxing words as they bathed her face.</l>
    .<l n="c">The fear that filled her at their insistence, was plain to see</l>
    .<l n="d">As they escorted her back in soon after.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    4720<div type="canto" n="19">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thereupon, the heart of the lover she had abandoned in the beauty of that lovely bed-chamber became ever more inflamed.</l>
    .<l n="b">His tender gaze was heart-stopping and as sweet as a beautiful lotus.</l>
    .<l n="c">As rain in the fourth month, his words set her heart aquiver.</l>
    .<l n="d">He was like a yearning bee in the fragrant <foreign>asana,</foreign> intoxicated with beauty:</l>
    4725</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘O maiden, jewel of all who love, enthroned in the innermost depths of my yearning heart, you hold me spell-bound with passion,</l>
    .<l n="b">Bringing to me the sharpest love-pangs, your arching brows wound my shattered heart.</l>
    .<l n="c">How can I not die when your eyes shine upon me, filling me with feelings of longing?</l>
    .<l n="d">And in captivating me with desire, you become the essence that forever fills my heart.</l>
    4730</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘But even if I, your brother, were to die, I could become your eye-black, your ear-ornaments, your breast-band, your robe.</l>
    .<l n="b">What pleasure I would know in heightening the beauty of your heart-melting glance, or drawing near in homage to your fragrant ear.</l>
    .<l n="c">On the couch I could caress your breasts, marked with the scratches [of love-making] and enclose your beautiful, lustrous waist.</l>
    .<l n="d">My darling, what joy would be mine if I were thus allowed to inhale the scent of your beauty.’</l>
    4735</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">These were the prince’s loving words, telling her of the depth of his feelings, enchanting her.</l>
    .<l n="b">His words of love were fit to dispel the apprehension of any* love-lorn bride and put her fear to rest.</l>
    .<l n="c">But just as the sun grows cool at twilight, the princess was sad at heart and upset,</l>
    .<l n="d">And would not look at her lover’s delightful glances though, like syrup, they were sweet enough to carry her pain away.</l>
    4740</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">He found many sweet ways to alleviate the princess’s heartache.</l>
    .<l n="b">In joyful ecstasy, he kissed her as she lay with her head in his lap, stroking her breasts,</l>
    .<l n="c">Striving only for harmony in their love-making, steadfastly practising the meditation of the doctrines [of love],</l>
    .<l n="d">They seemed to drown in a sea of honey, caressed by the clouds of passion.</l>
    4745</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="20">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">After making love a second time, the princess was exhausted and deathly pale.</l>
    .<l n="b">Like the moon growing dim, the sweetness of her wan face had lost its lustre.</l>
    4750<l n="c">Moreover the lamps shining upon her enhanced her charm, captivating</l>
    .<l n="d">The prince, who because of his boundless love, became even more ardent.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The onlookers, hiding behind the partitions there, were overcome by feelings of longing, tinged with desire,</l>
    .<l n="b">On hearing the soft rustlings and whispered endearments which seemed only to enhance their love-making.</l>
    4755<l n="c">In time, weary of joining in love, they fell silent and slept, </l>
    .<l n="d">Without a thought for the clothes and wraps that they had left abandoned there, kicked aside.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">We will not tell of them as, replete with love-making, they slept* there on the couch.</l>
    .<l n="b">When day began to break, a fragrant breeze came wafting,</l>
    4760<l n="c">Carrying with it the perfume of the <foreign>srī gaḍing</foreign>, <foreign>asana </foreign>and <foreign>kamuning</foreign> flowers</l>
    .<l n="d">And the enchantment of secret places that, like a bed chamber, conjure up visions of love.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Delightfully, the distant call of the <foreign>kokila</foreign> could be faintly heard.</l>
    .<l n="b">The peacocks, carolling joyfully on the gate-posts, were enchanting.</l>
    4765<l n="c">The bees, buzzing in their hives, sounded like ardent husbands* kissing each of their wives</l>
    .<l n="d">In a frenzy of delight, aroused by the <foreign>asanas</foreign> and the fragrant, beautiful pandanus flowers.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="21">
    4770<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The bright Lord of the Sun was just beginning to shine</l>
    .<l n="b">As radiantly as a half smile that hints at passion.</l>
    .<l n="c">Glowing rays of light spread sparkling on all sides,</l>
    .<l n="d">And burnished* clouds shone with brilliant streaks.</l>
    .</p>
    4775<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The hand-maidens had completed their preparations,</l>
    .<l n="b">And stood in readiness on the outer verandah.</l>
    .<l n="c">They brought there all that they needed for bathing,</l>
    .<l n="d">With graceful* movements, full of happiness.</l>
    .</p>
    4780</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="22">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">But the loving couple, enveloped in weariness from love-making, did not know that day had come.</l>
    .<l n="b">They were surprised when they awoke to find their clothes in disarray and rearranged them.</l>
    .<l n="c">They emerged, eyes blinking, from the bridal chamber,</l>
    4785<l n="d">And were then bathed together by their attentive maids.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Emerging from the water,* they sat there together on the verandah outside the pavilion,</l>
    .<l n="b">Joyfully sitting so closely layered together,* with the princess on his lap,</l>
    .<l n="c">They looked as beautiful as a god and goddess descending from the heavens,</l>
    4790<l n="d">With the serving-girls waiting upon them, each appropriately adorned,* seated below them according to rank.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">They were ill-at-ease, lingering there on the verandah,</l>
    .<l n="b">Thrown into confusion by sudden thoughts of the sweetness of the partner who had brought them such bliss.</l>
    .<l n="c">The gleam in their love-filled eyes seemed to compel them to return,</l>
    4795<l n="d">And again they climbed up to the couch, there to discover the joy of their nakedness.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Truly splendid was all that was used to regale them during the marriage ceremonies.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Softly, as if to soothe them, the sweet strains of the <foreign>gəṇḍing</foreign> sang out their praises,</l>
    .<l n="c">And the fragrance of the perfumes, boreh and bdellium wafted there,</l>
    4800<l n="d">Thus arousing their passion and making them eager for love.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The fourth hour sounded out, a signal for them to come out of the pavilion together.</l>
    .<l n="b">Then delicious foods prepared in full measure were placed before them,</l>
    .<l n="c">The elderly women keeping close watch over every detail of the offerings,</l>
    4805<l n="d">As lute players and graceful dancers fulfilled their every request and desire.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">They became Kāma and Ratih as they sought union in the bed-chamber.</l>
    .<l n="b">Because of their boundless mutual passion they found harmony, burgeoning together in the raptures of love.</l>
    .<l n="c">Their enjoyment was that of the delighted meeting of the sap of the fruit of the betel and sharp tooth.</l>
    4810<l n="d">The consummation of their union awakening joy in the faces of her mother and father.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="23">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">With that, the king’s mind indeed became tranquil.</l>
    4815<l n="b">The joy of the people throughout the kingdom returned in equal measure.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Prosperity immediately brought back the might of heroes throughout the land,</l>
    .<l n="d">For there was nothing to trouble their hearts, all were equally untroubled.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will not tell of the many months that the two lovers lived in mutual delight,</l>
    4820<l n="b">Happy to be as one together, there in the palace.</l>
    .<l n="c">Their every action touched their hearts to the core,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Their love for each other like that of the <foreign>mangunəng</foreign> flower, closely entwined with the <foreign>jangga</foreign> vine.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">And so the king knew unbounded love in great measure, </l>
    4825<l n="b">Because the prince had caused his heart to be free of care,</l>
    .<l n="c">And so he formed a deep and lasting affection for Pārtha,</l>
    .<l n="d">While love for him blossomed in the hearts of his people and army.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The rumbling thunder [of the fourth month], that season that summons wanderers to surrender themselves to the pursuit of beauty, arrived.</l>
    4830<l n="b">The prince’s heart swelled to hear it</l>
    .<l n="c">And so he made preparations to go in search of the beauty of nature, </l>
    .<l n="d">His mind dwelling constantly on thoughts of bathing places, oft frequented.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Having received the consent of his beloved, he took leave</l>
    4835<l n="b">First, of the king and queen</l>
    .<l n="c">But we will pass over that. The next day, the prince set off, </l>
    .<l n="d">Accompanied by a royal escort, fully equipped, lined up in formation.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    4840<div type="canto" n="24">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Delightful were the lovely fragrances from the flower gardens as the breeze caught them. The cry of the peacock was enchanting,</l>
    .<l n="b">As the prince made his preparations to set off without delay from the royal palace and went on his way.</l>
    .<l n="c">Night had passed and the landscape came into view through a curtain of falling rain.</l>
    .<l n="d">For all the world like jewels scattered everywhere, rain drops filled the fields.</l>
    4845</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The newly-risen sun shone in the east, a shower of sparkling rays radiating down into the mountain gullies.</l>
    .<l n="b">The glittering forest trees were at their best, their shimmering branches vibrant.</l>
    .<l n="c">The joyful sound of the wood-fowl* in the gorges rang out,* as male and female, in repose, called back and forth* to each other.</l>
