    .<l n="d">And the cuckoo’s cry sounded loudly* as if inspired by the mountain view.</l>
    4850</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Trees that had abandoned hope and shrivelled, now bathed with dew,* put forth new leaves.</l>
    .<l n="b">Delightedly, young bael creepers* opened, thrusting their tendrils out sideways.</l>
    .<l n="c">Curling fronds of <foreign>katirah</foreign> spiralled down and blended into the gold* trees,</l>
    .<l n="d">Encircling the overhanging <foreign>wanañjari</foreign>* in its embrace, as if longing to form a bower* for lovers.</l>
    4855</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Along the sides of the mountain ridges, the cultivated fields, lit by the sun’s rays, gleamed.</l>
    .<l n="b">Ivory betel-nut palms, heavily laden with coconuts, their fruit ripe for picking, stood in delightful rows.</l>
    .<l n="c">On the slopes were verdant rice-fields, bananas grew abundantly in the ravines,</l>
    .<l n="d">Their leaves, lying on the ground where they had fallen, like blunted styluses.</l>
    4860</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The crops were green and lovely, freshly shining, wet with dew.</l>
    .<l n="b">Millet and rattan, tuberous roots and <foreign>payanggu</foreign> were in full bloom, there were aubergines neatly planted along the small dykes.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Garden plots had been established in the near-by valleys, the glistening soil newly tilled.</l>
    .<l n="d">Unfolding taro, just beginning to show its flowers,* looked like rolled-leaf ear ornaments of ivory.</l>
    4865</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The graceful young leaves of the <foreign>lirang</foreign> looked for all the world like the naked waists of maidens.</l>
    .<l n="b">As if throwing themselves down on the ground in dejection, prey to feelings of longing and sadness, the withering <foreign>jangga</foreign> vines were mad with desire.</l>
    .<l n="c">The ivory coconuts were like uncovered breasts in the fullness of their beauty,</l>
    .<l n="d">Indeed, they seemed to have stolen the loveliness of a yearning maiden, secretly seeking the raptures of love.</l>
    4870</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a"><foreign>Cangkilung</foreign> birds sang sweetly in the ravines, accompanied by the answering calls of <foreign>pings</foreign>.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Shyly they called out,* sobbing and yearning as they waited in the <foreign>rangin</foreign> trees.</l>
    .<l n="c">‘Ooooo’, came the soughing of the rustling wind, whistling through* the <foreign>wungwang</foreign> bamboo,* bringing delight,</l>
    .<l n="d">And just to hear the heart-stopping cry of the <foreign>pakṣi kətur</foreign> birds seemed* to awaken emotions of love.</l>
    4875</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="25">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">As the prince proceeded on his journey, one splendid vista after another unfolded before his eyes.</l>
    .<l n="b">Emerging from a leafy wood, he entered a peaceful valley.</l>
    4880<l n="c">The dry rice-fields were beautiful, their plants a balm to the eyes.*</l>
    .<l n="d">What a pity they had been so neglected! Perhaps hermits who had once sought solitude* there had been rendered powerless by magical forces and worsted.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Along the sides of the path, well-kept fields rising up in terraces </l>
    .<l n="b">Towered above the settlements located at the foot of the mountain.</l>
    4885<l n="c">In the bright sunlight, he could see them all clearly as he looked down,</l>
    .<l n="d">But they disappeared from view as they zigzagged* in and out of the distant hollows.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The gardens came right up to the undergrowth* which seemed intent on invading the hermitage,</l>
    .<l n="b">But it seemed to hesitate uncertainly, lest in the heat of the sun, the valley road would be as [hot as] a cauldron,*</l>
    4890<l n="c">It kept constant guard against the wickedness* of the naughty monkeys, seeking to steal the plants and crops,</l>
    .<l n="d">As well as the terrible forest boars that were treacherously determined to destroy everything,* so fierce were they.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Stands of bending ivory coconut palms charmingly waiting there on the hill, beckoned.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Delightful in their exuberance,* they lent enchantment to the haunts of poets composing verse,</l>
    4895<l n="c">But their invitation to the chattering lemurs, half-hidden there, seemed to no avail*</l>
    .<l n="d">In the face of the incessant loud clattering of the alarms* that frightened them all away unharmed.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Determined to convey the message of beauty, <foreign>gagarangan</foreign> trees* bedecked themselves with garlands of flower, </l>
    .<l n="b">But they had forgotten their true nature - that they had no fragrance at all - and stood tall and lofty.*</l>
    4900<l n="c">In boldly challenging the beauty of <foreign>asanas</foreign> in the fourth month like this and trying to replace it,</l>
    .<l n="d">They were quite in error, for it was quite impossible they could ever cause desire.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The <foreign>kamwagan</foreign> diffused its fragrance to envelop the artful <foreign>pupulutan</foreign>*flowers.</l>
    .<l n="b">Wanting to mingle together with them and give prominence to its own perfume,* it seemed to take delight* in such fraudulent and impudent behaviour.</l>
    4905<l n="c">Enhancing its beauty with red <foreign>pilapilu,</foreign>* gleefully planning to lie in wait in the gullies,</l>
    .<l n="d">The <foreign>singgugu</foreign> shrub lay ready, its flowers languidly scattered and strewn about to form a mat.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">In full blossom, the <foreign>wunga tali</foreign> seemed to tremble, giving itself airs, though it seemed absurd that it could ever wound a heart.</l>
    .<l n="b">Far from hiding itself away, it acted quite wrongly, showing too little self control.</l>
    4910<l n="c">As if maddened, it tried to discover the secrets of the <foreign>mandalīka</foreign> calling to it, though it sullenly shook its head,</l>
    .<l n="d">Drawing itself up to its full height, ignoring the passion that filled it, reached outwards, and was trapped.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">In this way, the beauties of the countryside were set before the prince on his journey.</l>
    .<l n="b">The ascetics all came out according to rank to meet him as he travelled on his way,</l>
    4915<l n="c">Bidding him welcome, warmly offering him every efficacious herb and medicine as well as delicious fruits.</l>
    .<l n="d">Joyfully, and attentive to every detail, he [in turn] presented them with the gifts due from a prince.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Many country people, not to mention a great number of their leaders, attended him.</l>
    .<l n="b">Abundant were their gifts of delicacies: there were fruits and roots and sweet, young coconuts,</l>
    4920<l n="c">Palm wine and <foreign>kilang.</foreign>* All that they had in their stores, they offered humbly,</l>
    .<l n="d">Pleasing the prince so much that he wished to linger there.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">By the time he was ready to set off again to visit the many beauty spots in the forest, </l>
    .<l n="b">The sun had set, and so he made ready to spend the night,</l>
    4925<l n="c">There, in the hermitage, with his entire escort* carefully keeping watch,</l>
    .<l n="d">While all the <foreign>duwan</foreign>* came forward in rank to attend to his every need.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="26">
    4930<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">When night had passed, the prince again went on his way in search of beauty,</l>
    .<l n="b">Making his way along the edges of the ravines, along the dips and bends of the magnificent mountain.</l>
    .<l n="c">He was charmed by the sound of the musical watermills, faintly audible in the distance, tinkling sweetly one after the other in the gullies.</l>
    .<l n="d">The muted roar of a waterfall, that could be heard now and then, entranced him.</l>
    .</p>
    4935<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Valleys lay open to view in the curves of the hills, the forests along their slopes</l>
    .<l n="b">So charmingly spread out below, but covered now with white clouds, were scarcely visible.</l>
    .<l n="c">Low clouds came down, blanketing them, then dispersing again like the remnants of night,</l>
    .<l n="d">So that for a moment the <foreign>walik-aḍəp</foreign> trees* flickered, then, as if suddenly called away, unable to wait, vanished.</l>
    .</p>
    4940<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The sun now shone as radiantly as the face of a beloved in the bed-chamber.</l>
    .<l n="b">Taking flight, the dew formed stripes on the grass then sought a hiding place.</l>
    .<l n="c">As the mist was finally swept away, the hermitages on the hill sides, where the ascetics dwelt, </l>
    .<l n="d">Burnished brightly by the sun, were like white doves flashing past.</l>
    .</p>
    4945<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Gleefully, the members of his escort* scattered, spreading out everywhere along the valleys, clinging* to the mountain ridges.</l>
    .<l n="b">Some were leaping about, others made their way* to peaks north and south.</l>
    .<l n="c">Merrily, joyfully, seeking out the delights of the forested hills.</l>
    .<l n="d">The reverberating sounds of their hunting* echoed as they wandered about there tumultuously.</l>
    .</p>
    4950<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Content, the prince descended from his chariot and went off in search of the beauties of nature.</l>
    .<l n="b">‘Indeed I will go into the woods, there I will surely find them’, he thought to himself,</l>
    .<l n="c">And he went on unescorted, separating himself from the others so that there would be none to observe him.</l>
    .<l n="d">Then gradually leaving them behind, he wandered further away, ever more absorbed in beauty.</l>
    .</p>
    4955<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The prince now became enthralled by the delightful ornaments that the forest held in readiness for him.</l>
    .<l n="b">Far below, a small pavilion that looked like a mushroom nestling on the steep slopes of the rocky, pitted terrain, bade him welcome.</l>
    .<l n="c">There the prince rested, gazing intently up at the splendid roof-beam,</l>
    .<l n="d">Where a name, faint now but still distinguishable, remained there for others to find and ponder.</l>
    .</p>
    4960<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">He could just make out another hermitage at the edge of the ravine which majestically towered above.</l>
    .<l n="b">The penance of the ascetics who lived there must have been powerful beyond words,</l>
    .<l n="c">For they were served* by female ascetics who would certainly bring failure to any who strove* to subdue their senses,</l>
    .<l n="d">Always planning to weave their charms to bewitch* the concentration of the seers.</l>
    .</p>
    4965<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">A gliding river of unearthly beauty appeared like a vision in a dream,</l>
    .<l n="b">And from the mountain peak high above, it seemed to have formed a beach below.</l>
    .<l n="c">Along the edges of its beautiful banks, rock-platforms waited invitingly,</l>
    .<l n="d">As if to decree that such beauty depicted in verse, could only be found in the poem of the prince of poets.</l>
    .</p>
    4970<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">In the middle of the water, he could just make out a reef, thrusting upward.</l>
    .<l n="b">Even as the waves washed over it, caressing it and bespattering it with water, it stood unyielding.</l>
    .<l n="c">Moreover, a veil of spray sought out the graceful pandanus draped* there,</l>
    .<l n="d">With their naked flowers trailing, as if to capture the attention of wanderers in pursuit of beauty.</l>
    .</p>
    4975<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">On reflection, these subtle hints of the wondrous appearance of the river-bank seemed</l>
    .<l n="b">Designed to distract even the rapt attention of the one seeking the riddle of a name.</l>
    .<l n="c"><foreign>Kinnara </foreign>birds* and swallows flew down to it.</l>
    .<l n="d">Some became entangled in the reeds* after bathing there, longing* to find a resting place to share.</l>
    .</p>
    4980<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Herons swam in formation in the water, some standing there like mendicant monks,</l>
    .<l n="b">Preening their feathers* as an excuse for looking intently* into the holes of the mud-eels.</l>
    .<l n="c">Merrily, the warblers twittered incessantly, then went off together in pairs, flying into the air.</l>
    .<l n="d">The peacocks fell silent, content to go on dancing and remain in the water.</l>
    .</p>
    4985</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="27">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The prince became more and more delighted when he saw</l>
    .<l n="b">That pure and crystal-clear mountain stream,</l>
    .<l n="c">And so, drawing near to bathe his face,</l>
    4990<l n="d">He descended to the depths of that flawless river.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">There he performed the most excellent, paramount ritual gestures,</l>
    .<l n="b">Praying to the Lord of One Thousand Rays, the Sun.</l>
    .<l n="c">Together with the recitation of esoteric formulas,* his meditation</l>
    4995<l n="d">Penetrated to the highest* inconceivable truth.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="28">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">As the excellent Phalguṇa was praying, his mind calm and undisturbed, tranquil and pure,*</l>
    5000<l n="b">A gigantic, mighty crocodile, guardian of the river, suddenly appeared.</l>
    .<l n="c">Its presence there was the reason that no-one* came near and that it was so deserted,</l>
    .<l n="d">But now it caught the fragrant scent of the noble Pārtha. </l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Immediately, its ferocity awakened, for it was wild with hunger,</l>
    5005<l n="b">Burning with savage frenzy, so long had it been without food.</l>
    .<l n="c">There it was spanning* the river, its mouth open wide, its fangs protruding sideways,</l>
    .<l n="d">And protuberances* all over its face, so that it resembled the terrifying and awesome [demon] Rāhu.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">It saw the prince, undaunted and confident,</l>
    5010<l n="b">Awaiting its attack. Swiftly it drew near,* but just as it was about to pounce,</l>
    .<l n="c">He too advanced steadily, joined with it, </l>
    .<l n="d">Spinning around and feinting fearlessly.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Swiftly, loudly, they clashed, keeping each other constantly in view, and as they came to grips,</l>
    5015<l n="b">The river seemed to open wide, its waters rising up and crashing down.</l>
    .<l n="c">As if it were being stirred, it eddied in the centre, mud spewed forth,</l>
    .<l n="d">As if they were scooping it up as they assailed each other, angrily attacking.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">In violent commotion, they circled each other, lunging unexpectedly, grappling tirelessly, never weakening,</l>
    5020<l n="b">Skilfully and confidently attacking each other from all sides, without fear.</l>
    .<l n="c">In turn they grabbed at each other, clawed at each other, locked in the battle of their furious assault,</l>
    .<l n="d">Sometimes dancing about each other in their struggle, then joining once again in combat.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">It seemed their struggle would never end, when, suddenly,* the crocodile looked to be worsted,</l>
    5025<l n="b">Momentarily off-guard, as Arjuna quickly seized it and spun it around as if it were weightless.</l>
    .<l n="c">He dashed it down swiftly* upon a sharp rock, breaking its jaw,</l>
    .<l n="d">Its neck* snapped and thus it was rendered powerless by Phalguṇa.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">With that, the prince hauled it to the surface of the earth.</l>
    5030<l n="b">He looked in amazement upon its appearance in death.</l>
    .<l n="c">For he thought himself bewitched, as he gazed upon a heavenly nymph.</l>
    .<l n="d">Indeed, he could only think that this dead monster was strikingly beautiful.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">An uninterrupted rain of flowers fell on the prince;</l>
    5035<l n="b">Buzzing bees circled him, moving from flower to flower.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Such was the gift of homage that fell at the feet of Phalguṇa</l>
    .<l n="d">And the prince, deeply gratified, sought an explanation.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    5040<div type="canto" n="29">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Then the heavenly nymph spoke out.</l>
    .<l n="b">‘Indeed, I, your servant, am a celestial being,</l>
    .<l n="c">An attendant of the renowned Dhanādhipa.</l>
    .<l n="d">My name is none other than Sarwadā.*</l>
    5045</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘I also have four beautiful sisters, nymphs all,</l>
    .<l n="b">Who wandered with me in search of pleasures.</l>
    .<l n="c">We came to the district of Alakāwatī,</l>
    .<l n="d">To the garden of the gods, the beautiful Amarāwatī.*</l>
    5050</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘There a great seer was performing powerful yoga,</l>
    .<l n="b">Undertaking religious austerities, without equal in the three worlds.</l>
    .<l n="c">But we then disturbed his meditation,</l>
    .<l n="d">As if driven to it by some evil force.</l>
    5055</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘In his anger he cast a curse upon us: “Hey! You who scorn me!</l>
    .<l n="b">May you become wicked crocodiles, desiring only to kill the creatures of the world!”</l>
    .<l n="c">Having cursed us thus, he then vanished,</l>
    .<l n="d">Leaving us confused and heart-sore.</l>
    5060</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘We then moved swiftly off in search of a river.</l>
    .<l n="b">When we came to Awindhya, we came upon him again.</l>
    .<l n="c">Together we fell at his feet and paid homage to him,</l>
    .<l n="d">Begging him in his mercy to grant us a counter-curse.*</l>
    5065</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Since he cared for the welfare of others and was of patient mind,</l>
    .<l n="b">Compassionate, because we had bowed down before him, expressing our submission,</l>
    .<l n="c">He bestowed upon us the blessing of his mercy and granted us the gift of a limit to the curse,</l>
    .<l n="d">So that we might once again become pure beings.</l>
    5070</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘ “Resign yourselves! Soon it will come to pass</l>
    .<l n="b">That one called Pārtha, the son of Pāṇḍu,</l>
    .<l n="c">Will come journeying here.*</l>
    .<l n="d">He will draw you from the water, and you will again become divine.”</l>
    5075</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘With those words he went on his way.</l>
    .<l n="b">We set out together to seek a secluded place to dwell.</l>
    .<l n="c">Later we came here to the River Swabhadra</l>
    .<l n="d">And became these vile crocodiles.</l>
    5080</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘Many ages have we spent in despair,</l>
    .<l n="b">Always starving, with nothing to eat, barely alive and weakened.</l>
    .<l n="c">Deer, serpents - any that came here to drink the water -</l>
    .<l n="d">Surely died, as we killed, destroyed, devoured.</l>
    5085</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘And so we never saw a living soul.</l>
    .<l n="b">Feared by all, the enemy of all here,</l>
    .<l n="c">Becoming hungrier and hungrier in our pitiable, miserable condition*</l>
    .<l n="d">Brought low by the overpowering force of our wicked, impure hearts.</l>
    5090</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">‘But now that you are here, my dream has been fulfilled.</l>
    .<l n="b">Through you, I am again a nymph.</l>
    .<l n="c">Incomparable and boundless is my debt to you,</l>
    .<l n="d">For you have drawn me out of the misery of hell.*</l>
    5095</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">‘Forgive me! If you consider it proper,</l>
    .<l n="b">Would you now go on to rescue my sisters,</l>
    .<l n="c">For they have been left languishing sorrowfully,</l>
    .<l n="d">And are all waiting in the river?’</l>
    5100</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="30">
    . <p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus said the celestial woman to the noble Pārtha.</l>
    .<l n="b">The prince was willing to accede to her gentle words.</l>
    5105<l n="c">Setting off* with the heavenly nymph,</l>
    .<l n="d">They travelled swiftly, without stopping to rest.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">They came to the beautiful but inaccessible pools where the other crocodiles lived.</l>
    .<l n="b">There he lifted them up and released them all.</l>
    5110<l n="c">They were delighted to be nymphs once again,</l>
    .<l n="d">And all paid homage to the noble son of Pāṇḍu.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘O Lord Pārtha! Virtuously you strive for the welfare of the world.</l>
    .<l n="b">You are indeed our protector, possessed of sanctifying power.</l>
    5115<l n="c">Truly you are Wiṣṇu incarnate</l>
    .<l n="d">And the glow of your virtue fills the three worlds.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Thus they spoke. The prince was delighted:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘O nymphs! How could I fail in my purpose?</l>
    5120<l n="c">It was only the proper <foreign>dharma</foreign>* of a man of virtue in this world</l>
    .<l n="d">That I have followed, in taking upon myself* the burden of your sorrow.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">It was not for silver, gold, jewels or profit</l>
    .<l n="b">That I rescued you from your time of trouble.</l>
    5125<l n="c">It befits a <foreign>kṣatriya</foreign> warrior to ensure no cruelty befalls the world.</l>
    .<l n="d">He should strive only to devote himself to such meritorious deeds.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Thus said the excellent Pārtha in explanation.</l>
    .<l n="b">It was as if the heavenly nymphs had been sprinkled with the water of life,</l>
    5130<l n="c">For they had received his most exalted favour,</l>
    .<l n="d">And did not know how to repay such kindness that was as great as Mount Meru.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘We have enjoyed your unbounded favour,</l>
    .<l n="b">Our debt is without limit, never can we [repay it].*</l>
    5135<l n="c">May you be unimpeded, my lord, in obtaining your desires and the victory you seek!</l>
    .<l n="d">You are indeed the refuge of the defenceless, O protector of the earth!’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Many were their praises of Prince Pārtha.</l>
    .<l n="b">We will not tell of them. Having taken leave of him,</l>
    5140<l n="c">They departed without delay and, in a flash, flew away together into the sky,</l>
    .<l n="d">Towards heaven. But we will say no more of this.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Pārtha was left alone, love-lorn and weak with desire,</l>
    .<l n="b">Prey to his emotions as he stared up into the heavens, totally bemused.</l>
    5145<l n="c">His heart missed a sudden beat as he caught the sound of distant thunder,</l>
    .<l n="d">There in the west, for it seemed like the voices of those heavenly women.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">For a long time he sat in contemplation. When the sun had gone down</l>
    .<l n="b">It became even more still there on the bank of the river.</l>
    5150<l n="c">Gently* it whispered [to him] as he watched the eddying stream. </l>
    .<l n="d">‘I have been purified,’ it rippled, in proof that its waters* were free of danger.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Now we will tell of the members of his escort who came running up at the double,</l>
    .<l n="b">Competing with each other to be first there, trying to overtake each other.</l>
    5155<l n="c">With great merriment and in high spirits, some engaged in ferocious hand-to hand-combat,</l>
    .<l n="d">So eager were they to hear about the heavenly women.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">And so the prince waited there.</l>
    .<l n="b">But we will tell now of the great ascetics of the hermitage.</l>
    5160<l n="c">All who lived in the vicinity of the Swabhadra river</l>
    .<l n="d">Had heard of the removal of the danger from their holy bathing place.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">They were so delighted to be afraid no longer,</l>
    .<l n="b">That they quickly set off together to go* at once to the noble one.</l>
    5165<l n="c">Coming upon the excellent Pārtha resting there,</l>
    .<l n="d">They were astounded by his splendid appearance.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Arjuna greeted the arrival of the hermits with great respect</l>
    .<l n="b">And sat politely, legs crossed, quiet and tranquil.</l>
    5170<l n="c">The sages* said: ‘How fortunate it is that you have come here now</l>
    .<l n="d">To the Swabhadra, the lovely abode of we hermits.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">‘And we say to you, O Prince, that by your actions in coming to these wooded mountains,</l>
    .<l n="b">What you have accomplished is truly great.* You are the recourse of us who strive.</l>
    5175<l n="c">Your victory in this world is clearly ordained by the gods.</l>
    .<l n="d">Indeed, we believe that you will obtain your goal and all that you strive for.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">Thus said the seers. The prince replied sincerely,</l>
    .<l n="b">‘As you look so kindly, Sirs, on one such as I, </l>
    5180<l n="c">May I be the sacrifice for you whose aim is to perform virtuous deeds,</l>
    .<l n="d">In your wish to be free of the <foreign>karma</foreign> of the three worlds.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">These were his words. Thereupon, in homage they brought him</l>
    .<l n="b">Water to wash his feet, water to rinse his mouth, such as is due to a guest, as well as betel leaf and nut,</l>
    5185<l n="c">And medicinal herbs, not to mention delicious fruits and tubers.</l>
    .<l n="d">All were offered to him by the anchoresses with all requisite ceremony.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">They were amazed just to look upon the noble Pārtha.</l>
    .<l n="b">‘How extraordinary he is! He is the god of Love who has come here to earth,</l>
    5190<l n="c">With the purpose of hunting out beauty, consuming us with fire,</l>
    .<l n="d">Spitefully destroying our vows and meditation,’ they thought.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">Then the groups of hermits all decreed</l>
    .<l n="b">That Pārtha should immediately be honoured by the seers* themselves.</l>
    5195<l n="c">When he had been thus honoured,* he became even more content</l>
    .<l n="d">And after a while the great abbot again spoke:</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">‘O Prince! You are our most excellent refuge,</l>
    .<l n="b">Protecting all the monks and their kin.</l>
    5200<l n="c">Because none but you has the gift of your virtuous nature*</l>
    .<l n="d">We have witnessed* your triumph as you have attained your desires.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="21"><l n="a">‘And yet I will offer you my insignificant advice, if you will but listen.</l>
    .<l n="b">As long as happiness increases, then difficulties will be suffered.</l>
    5205<l n="c">The origin of the love of others is invisible and therefore it is eternal.</l>
    .<l n="d">It is thus the most important thing, the foremost embodiment of <foreign>dharma</foreign>.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="22"><l n="a">‘For this [love] alone, you should truly search the depths of the self,*</l>
    .<l n="b">Just as the foremost champion in battle always* fosters unity,</l>
    5210<l n="c">So that proper conduct ensues and thereby increases,</l>
    .<l n="d">And his enemies, therefore, cannot attack.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="23"><l n="a">‘It is no different in the three worlds than in your body.</l>
    .<l n="b">There can be no hostility because of kindness and freedom from passion. </l>
    5215<l n="c">Neither enemies from within nor without can assail you.</l>
    .<l n="d">And you can be wholly unconstrained* and free from danger in obtaining your desires.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="24"><l n="a">Thus was the form of the doctrine that he expounded* so properly.</l>
    .<l n="b">Dhanañjaya welcomed it,</l>
    5220<l n="c">For indeed its sentiments were truly appropriate.</l>
    .<l n="d">In short this was their discussion. But we will say no more of it.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="25"><l n="a">Night fell and the excellent and noble Pārtha spent it</l>
    .<l n="b">There in the hermitage, the ascetics,*</l>
    5225<l n="c">Full of laughter and delight discussed* how the prosperity of the hermitage</l>
    .<l n="d">Had been magically altered by the prince’s supernatural potency.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="26"><l n="a">The prince enjoyed staying there in the place that had been prepared for him</l>
    .<l n="b">In an open pavilion, bright, clean and well-appointed.</l>
    5230<l n="c">In his private quarters, he was again fêted,</l>
    .<l n="d">For the community of ascetics was not yet ready to retire.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="27"><l n="a">In every respect the enchanting hermitage, so still and lovely, was delightful,</l>
    .<l n="b">With the moon adding the lustre* of its pale, gleaming rays</l>
    5235<l n="c">Like a lamp shining down upon the lights of the hermitage.</l>
    .<l n="d">The wafting fragrance of the lovely areca blossoms permeated everywhere.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="28"><l n="a">Disturbed and stirred by the delightful sighing of the ivory bamboo swaying in the cooling breeze,</l>
    .<l n="b">The bees sobbed in their holes with muffled song,</l>
    5240<l n="c">Beset by love-sickness now that night had come and they were separated* from the <foreign>aśoka</foreign> and <foreign>tañjung</foreign> flowers,</l>
    .<l n="d">Arousing feelings of tender emotion in the prince’s heart.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="29"><l n="a">The seers discoursed happily on many matters</l>
    .<l n="b">And the prince, Phalguṇa, was delighted to join in,</l>
    5245<l n="c">Now that the heavenly women had been restored to their true nature.</l>
    .<l n="d">But we will not tell of the night. It quickly passed.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="30"><l n="a">The following morning, the prince went from there.</l>
    .<l n="b">His journey along the forest paths* will not be recounted.</l>
    5250<l n="c">He came to Mayūra, where he was greeted with joy,</l>
    .<l n="d">By all the delighted women of the palace.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="31">
    5255<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">On his return he lived in contentment with his wife in the palace for a long time.</l>
    .<l n="b">The whole country was overwhelmed by perfect joy,</l>
    .<l n="c">And the king was transported with delight because of Arjuna.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will pass over how they came together in harmony in joyous love-making.</l>
    5260<l n="b">They brought into the world a child, a model of comeliness and virtue,</l>
    .<l n="c">The excellent Wabhruwāhana, who was presented [to the king] by his father.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The king then performed the many excellent rituals prescribed, </l>
    .<l n="b">Overjoyed to obtain this jewel of the ocean.</l>
    5265<l n="c">Such was the king’s happiness.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">None other than the prince himself occupied the hearts of the whole court, particularly those of the inner appartments.</l>
    .<l n="b">They wished to serve him alone,</l>
    .<l n="c">For they looked to him to be the protector of the world.</l>
    5270</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Their former sorrow was best described* as that of blades of grass,</l>
    .<l n="b">Withering as they hoped for rain to fall from the clouds.</l>
    .<l n="c">Now, deluged with rain, they were truly bursting with new life.</l>
    .</p>
    5275<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">All the royal domains, even the rural districts, were perfect.</l>
    .<l n="b">All were prosperous, no longer over-shadowed,</l>
    .<l n="c">So radiant, they seemed to outshine the sun and the moon.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Long would be the telling of the joy throughout the land.</l>
    5280<l n="b">Our account now turns again to the prince,</l>
    .<l n="c">Who kept constantly in mind the advice of the great ascetic.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Furthermore, the end of the eleventh year had almost arrived,</l>
    .<l n="b">And so he again prepared to move on,</l>
    5285<l n="c">His resolute heart unwavering.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The prince took his beloved in his arms and addressed her with consoling words,</l>
    .<l n="b">Telling her of his certain promise,</l>
    .<l n="c">That in the future he would return to serve her.*</l>
    5290</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">The excellent princess, fully understanding his intention, was untroubled</l>
    .<l n="b">Indeed, she never deviated from the teachings of highest truth,</l>
    .<l n="c">Unwilling to transgress [what is expected of] a beautiful woman.*</l>
    .</p>
    5295<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">So, worthy princess that she was, she did not demur,</l>
    .<l n="b">Unable to entertain evil thoughts,</l>
    .<l n="c">Even if ordered to undertake lowly work.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">So Dhanañjaya appeared in the presence of the king to take his leave.</l>
    5300<l n="b">The king offered no opposition,</l>
    .<l n="c">For he was truly a virtuous and honest man, a worthy example to the world.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="32">
    5305<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">In short, after he had sought leave to depart he went from the palace straight away.</l>
    .<l n="b">He walked without haste along the path, relaxed and totally absorbed in beauty.</l>
    .<l n="c">He was filled with wonder at the sight of all the scenic beauties of the country-side, which seemed never to weary of trying to detain him, holding themselves in readiness* for him.</l>
    .<l n="d">Standing ready in the hope that they would catch sight of him, they waited overhead.</l>
    .</p>
    5310<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Both sides of the path seemed to have spread out their charms for his sideways glance.</l>
    .<l n="b">So astounded were they, and so oppressed with grief when he passed them by, that they could only stand there.</l>
    .<l n="c">As if disturbed and despondent, the red flowers of the flame tree sighed and trembled when he ignored them.</l>
    .<l n="d">Tossing restlessly, the bamboos swayed back and forth, exhausted as the wind beat them and they knocked against each other.</l>
    .</p>
    5315<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">There was a settlement of great splendour, its many buildings scattered here and there, the pathways knowing how to give pleasure.</l>
    .<l n="b">Its carefully tended beauty was its gift of welcome if any should happen by.</l>
    .<l n="c">Along the edge was a pure mountain stream, encircling the sides of the square,</l>
    .<l n="d">Where women went to draw water from the bathing pools, while others immersed themselves,* all were beautiful to behold.</l>
    .</p>
    5320<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">It certainly seemed as if they wanted to conceal themselves within an encircling ring of relatives.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Their graceful movements were accompanied by the enchanting tabours, sweetly keeping tune with the <foreign>kangsi</foreign>.</l>
    .<l n="c">How tantalizing* they were as they adorned themselves with flowers, the flower ornaments in their hair bands were beautifully arranged,</l>
    .<l n="d">But as they made their flower offerings, they became agitated at seeing the splendid prince as he passed by.</l>
    .</p>
    5325<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">How delightful were the charms that the prince beheld as he went on his way.</l>
    .<l n="b">There was a row of springs, with fountains cascading down to form a crystal-clear pond,</l>
    .<l n="c">A place where fresh lotuses gathered to form an encircling wall which, like the face of a beautiful girl, overflowed with sweetness,</l>
    .<l n="d">Their beauty constantly veiled by the spray of the water which covered them like fragrant powder.</l>
    .</p>
    5330<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The outer walls were magnificent, perfect in design and construction.</l>
    .<l n="b">The walls of the storehouses* within were made of bricks and merged into the enclosing parapet with its towering gateways.</l>
    .<l n="c">Wholly unconstrained, fronds of slender <foreign>bhujanggapuṣpa</foreign> beckoned excitedly, </l>
    .<l n="d">As the wind continually pestered them wickedly, and they tossed and waved.</l>
    .</p>
    5335<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">As if to ornament the radiant beauty of the <foreign>jring</foreign>, the beautiful <foreign>wəlas-harəp</foreign> creeper was like a cloth of gold.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Showing themselves in all their richness, the magnificent red lotuses* were skilled at enticing* the lovely umbrella-pandanus [to open].</l>
    .<l n="c">The bees took flight as if, now they were no longer able to caress or ravish the flowers, they had come to a sudden stop, filled with great disappointment,</l>
    .<l n="d">And seemed to lose heart as the wind, telling them of charms of the jasmine, pushed them roughly aside.</l>
    .</p>
    5340<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Moreover, the lovely marsh-land enhanced the splendour of the scene depicted.</l>
    .<l n="b">Its charms seemed to long to accompany the prince on his journey, and reached out to draw near him.</l>
    .<l n="c">Looking down, he could see the delightful banks where pandanus, pendant with flowers, grew along the edges</l>
    .<l n="d">And a rich profusion of radiant <foreign>śatapatra</foreign> lotuses opened out their shimmering petals and beckoned to the bees.</l>
    .</p>
    5345<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The banks, where <foreign>surāga</foreign> and <foreign>rājasa</foreign> flowers blossomed,* were like a flower-strewn bed-chamber.</l>
    .<l n="b">The <foreign>campaka</foreign> were downcast, their display* to no avail because they had not yet been plucked by a wanderer in pursuit of beauty.</l>
    .<l n="c">Abandoned thus, they resigned themselves to their yearning, for no poet, eloping with his beloved, had come there to pick them,</l>
    .<l n="d">So that they were now willing to die and let their beauty slip away, by allowing their flowers to surrender their lives and float down, wilting, into the water.</l>
    .</p>
    5350<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">It would take too long to tell of the path or of the prince’s thoughts if we were to continue.</l>
    .<l n="b">He went quickly on his way. We will not tell of the time he spent surrendering himself to beauty.</l>
    .<l n="c">Soon after, he came to the shore,* where great beauty is ever to be found.</l>
    .<l n="d">So vast were its bright waters, that they seemed to merge on the horizon with the sky, then vanish from sight.</l>
    .</p>
    5355</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="33">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The shore-line brought him transports of delight,</l>
    .<l n="b">With its beautiful inlets, so enchanting.</l>
    .<l n="c">A river of clear water</l>
    5360<l n="d">Seemed to present its beauty as a gift to the ocean.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Birds wandered about in search of food* on the water’s edge.</l>
    .<l n="b">Some were white, and, as they meandered everywhere,*</l>
    .<l n="c">Stretching in a line, moving together in a row,</l>
    5365<l n="d">They were like jasmine flowers, worn in unbound tresses.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Like the unloosened ties of a <foreign>kain</foreign> were the ripple marks of the waves on the sand.</l>
    .<l n="b">Happily, the lovely <foreign>himi-himi</foreign> crabs rested there,</l>
    .<l n="c">Suddenly waving their pincers rapidly to and fro</l>
    5370<l n="d">As they scuttled away, burrowing down into the sand as the waves* receded.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">On an outcrop of glistening coral reef,</l>
    .<l n="b">Crabs were exposed and lay there clinging.</l>
    .<l n="c">Throngs* of mussels hung there, </l>
    5375<l n="d">Shining emerald-green* in the sun’s radiant light.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The many prawns, entrenched on the rocks,</l>
    .<l n="b">Frightened away the birds who were eyeing them.</l>
    .<l n="c">Some came soaring through the air, wanting to land there,</l>
    5380<l n="d">But they tried in vain to swoop down, for they were so startled, they flew off again in a flash.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">In great numbers, fish leapt up, thrown high in the air.</l>
    .<l n="b">One after the other they burst forth, darting to and fro.</l>
    .<l n="c">The porpoises and grey mullet, colliding,</l>
    5385<l n="d">Made the little fish dart away* as they hurtled down on top of them.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Waves rolled in, crashing down</l>
    .<l n="b">As if they had been tossed aside and hurled away by a huge <foreign>timi</foreign> fish.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Strands of seaweed* lay strewn about on all sides,</l>
    5390<l n="d">Like embroidered silk, decorating the wet sand.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Wave after wave crashed onto the shore</l>
    .<l n="b">Suddenly giving off a rain-bearing mist,</l>
    .<l n="c">Creating a shimmering rainbow</l>
    5395<l n="d">That extended, jewel-bright, as far as the eye could see.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Shellfish and mussels* of many sorts were scattered here and there</l>
    .<l n="b">On shining fronds* spread like mats.</l>
    .<l n="c">As the waves receded, they clattered,* trying to outdo each other,</l>
    5400<l n="d">Scraping continuously against the rocks in violent commotion.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">The foothills of the mountain were delightful.</l>
    .<l n="b">They extended far into the ocean’s maw.</l>
    .<l n="c">In the deep recesses of their caves, </l>
    5405<l n="d">Rock swallows slipped away, flying off together.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Far away in the distance was an island,</l>
    .<l n="b">Barely visible in the middle of the ocean.</l>
    .<l n="c">How attractively it rose up,</l>
    5410<l n="d">A target for the veiling mist that enshrouded it so delightfully.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">A line of boats, their sails set, </l>
    .<l n="b">Dazzling white, seemed to beckon, </l>
    .<l n="c">Telling of the riches they bore, </l>
    5415<l n="d">As they floated before the wind* on a voyage for treasure.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">Fishing boats* were everywhere, many far out in the middle of the ocean.</l>
    .<l n="b">Some, their decks at a precarious angle,* were being rowed.</l>
    .<l n="c">But others had overturned and, in distress, were being spun around and around</l>
    5420<l n="d">By monstrous fish, as huge as mountains.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">The roaring ocean rumbled loudly</l>
    .<l n="b">As if to summon a poet to compose a poem,</l>
    .<l n="c">Gracefully billowing, as if in restless torment,</l>
    5425<l n="d">To welcome Prince Pārtha joyfully.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="34">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">All he saw on his journey along the seashore was beautiful.</l>
    5430<l n="b">Moreover, as the sun rode over the western mountain, it took his breath away.</l>
    .<l n="c">Rising clouds of spray from the salters working on the banks of the river mouth,</l>
    .<l n="d">Evaporated, merging into the ocean haze, like lovers in intimate* meeting.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">There were rice fields and plantations of cotton trees in landscaped gardens.</l>
    5435<l n="b">As if uncertain of their charms, they presented the delights of their embankments to him.</l>
    .<l n="c">A multitude of <foreign>pasung*</foreign> milled together in welcome and flew in wave upon wave into the air,</l>
    .<l n="d">Leaving behind the crabs that stood so still they were hardly distinguishable in the roots of the <foreign>piḍaḍa</foreign> tree.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Herons flying homeward* side-by-side like strings of beads across the sky,</l>
    5440<l n="b">Were seeking a place to roost, for it had now become gloomy and cold.</l>
    .<l n="c">The sunbeams had just begun to lose their splendour in the ocean mist,</l>
    .<l n="d">In a flaming, bright red-gleaming bank of wispy clouds, like showering sparks.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Then, from the inlets along the rocky coast in the distance, came the faint glow</l>
    5445<l n="b">Of firelight that flared up with a burst of bright sparks.</l>
    .<l n="c">They looked like the reddened eyes* of a girl, languishing and forlorn, when overpowered on the couch,</l>
    .<l n="d">Or perhaps they were proclaiming that there was a village there, where travellers might spend a night by the shore.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">As the sun set, the trees shook visibly in the cold.</l>
    5450<l n="b">Now they had cast off the veiling mist of the ocean, they seemed truly downcast.</l>
    .<l n="c">On the eighth day of the dark half of the moon, when, in the middle of the night, the moon came out displaying itself in its fullness,</l>
    .<l n="d">He went on his journey again, after spending several nights sojourning there.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">In Prabhasa, the prince came upon a flawless and pure river,</l>
    5455<l n="b">Its mighty waters flowing pure and bright, renowned for their purificatory powers, the very water of life.</l>
    .<l n="c">This was the holy bathing place of the Yadu kingdom and none was more famous,</l>
    .<l n="d">For it was as peerless as the moonstone,* the source of the world’s creation.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">There the noble Dhanañjaya tarried a while and made his way along the banks.</l>
    5460<l n="b">Delightedly following the course of the Prabhasa, he then journeyed westward.</l>
    .<l n="c">He was entranced by the sight of all its delights that so assuaged* his weary heart,</l>
    .<l n="d">And ever welcomed him as he passed by, hoping he would linger.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Truly flawless was the river’s array, quite extraordinary its delights.</l>
    5465<l n="b">Many fallen and faded flowers,* left by those who came there to pray, had been abandoned there on the waves.</l>
    .<l n="c">Because of the unguents and saffron mixed together, it was always fragrant</l>
    .<l n="d">And members of the court came there daily, to bathe joyfully.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Indeed, its splendid snake-rock eclipsed the coral reefs of the ocean.</l>
    5470<l n="b">One rock completely covered by roots, looked like an elephant with a trunk.*</l>
    .<l n="c">All who roamed about in pursuit of beauty, carried away on the tide of passion, made their way there,</l>
    .<l n="d">And it was ever the destination of lovers, planning a secret rendezvous, stealing away quietly together to its banks.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">On either side, pandanus blossomed delightfully along the banks.</l>
    5475<l n="b">Beautiful to behold were the trailing flowers, some with petals half opened.</l>
    .<l n="c">When the bees sought them out, ensnared* by their fragrant pollen,</l>
    .<l n="d">They, like maidens overcome by heat,* were deflowered by them at will.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">No more will be said about the prince. Instead we will tell of Lord Kr̥ṣṇa.</l>
    5480<l n="b">On hearing that Pārtha, most excellent of princes, was there, he was delighted,</l>
    .<l n="c">And immediately commanded the noble Sāmba to go and invite the son of Pāṇḍu to visit.</l>
    .<l n="d">The Yadu warriors, mounted on horses, elephants and chariots, a strong guard attending them, provided the escort.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">On his arrival, Sāmba approached the son of Pāṇḍu to greet him warmly,</l>
    5485<l n="b">Saying, ‘Indeed, His Majesty invites you to come* to his court.</l>
    .<l n="c">Oh how happy is Kr̥ṣṇa and how delighted Baladewa too,</l>
    .<l n="d">Not to mention the entire Yadu tribe, all are overjoyed to hear [news] of you.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a"> ‘The king is presently on Mount Raiwata’s peak*</l>
    5490<l n="b">Performing ceremonies in honour of Wiṣṇu,* holding a great feast and carrying out the royal rites.</l>
    .<l n="c">Not a single Yadu has stayed behind at home, all are there, performing sacrifices and every ritual prescribed.</l>
    .<l n="d">Thus may you bear patiently with him that he is not in his palace.’</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    5495<div type="canto" n="35">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus the excellent, noble Sāmba addressed him respectfully. Dhanañjaya accepted,</l>
    .<l n="b">And they set out together, mounted in a chariot with all the Yadu hosts in attendance.</l>
    .<l n="c">Carefree and handsome were those who escorted them, all magnificent,</l>
    .<l n="d">And so the excellent Phalguṇa made his way to the mountain called Raiwata[ka].</l>
    5500</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will tell of the restlessness of the women throughout the land who, like flower-buds awaiting the sound of thunder,</l>
    .<l n="b">Had just now heard news of the prince’s arrival, that was to them like the harbinger of the fourth month.</l>
    .<l n="c">The concealed desire of these jewel-like women of the inner court suddenly blossomed forth and now showed outwardly.</l>
    .<l n="d">They did not know what to do, and unable to escape from their yearning, unable to forget what they had heard, were struck down by love.</l>
    5505</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Smitten by the new arrival, some plotted to ready their sweetness [for him].</l>
    .<l n="b">Others talked together, discussing him in soft whispers.</l>
    .<l n="c">So deeply* affected, cut to the very core of their being were they, that the mere mention of him aroused their desire,</l>
    .<l n="d">And they wanted to spread* a mat of flowers from their hair-knots before him, as a token* of their love.</l>
    5510</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">There were some who were so love-sick they thought only of love-making, their thoughts directed to him alone.</l>
    .<l n="b">Swooning, they longed fervently for his words of love to assuage the pain of their desire and bewilderment.</l>
    .<l n="c">So eager were they, they cast their beautiful bodies on the ground, that the sweetness of his glance might fall on them as rain,</l>
    .<l n="d">Heedless of the pain if it should pierce them through, happy to face the dangers of defeat at his hands.</l>
    5515</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">It would take too long to recount the thoughts of the court ladies, suffering from love pangs.</l>
    .<l n="b">Pārtha then reached King Harimūrti, there at the meeting place where the Yadu tribe had gathered.</l>
    .<l n="c">Foremost amongst them was Lord Baladewa. All were drawn up in formation, in the middle of the arena,</l>
    .<l n="d">A place of perfect brilliance because of the splendour of the god-like Yadus.</l>
    5520</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Arjuna’s arrival filled Kr̥ṣṇa’s heart with such elation</l>
    .<l n="b">That he welcomed him accordingly with heart-warming smiles and kindly words:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘Dear brother, I can hardly believe that I may now come face to face with your world-conquering glory.</l>
    .<l n="d">Receive this throne my dear brother, that I have laid ready for you in your absence.</l>
    5525</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘For some time I have kept watch over you, my dear, and have come to hear of your deeds as you have striven,</l>
    .<l n="b">To dwell continuously on the Hima mountain. How fortunate that we now should meet.</l>
    .<l n="c">The gods decree: “Remember also the difficulties of those who know pleasure and are not afflicted with calamity.”*</l>
    .<l n="d">Stay here in Dwārawatī, let it be your temporary home until the appointed time elapses and you can again return home.’</l>
    5530</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus said Lord Kr̥ṣṇa. The prince bowed low at his feet:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘If it please you,* Your Majesty, in truth it is you who are truly the foremost bestower of favours. Hail to you,* O righteous one!’</l>
    .<l n="c">This he said. In turn Halāyudha said respectfully to him:</l>
    .<l n="d">‘O my dear brother, indeed all the Yadus have certainly long awaited you.</l>
    5535</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘Your presence, my brother, will ensure that the rites which the Yadus now perform, will accomplish their aim perfectly.</l>
    .<l n="b">Please agree to take part so that through your participation, the welfare of the world will be assured.*</l>
    .<l n="c">By this alone can our journey be considered complete and enable us to return to the palace.</l>
    .<l n="d">Indeed, I will then accompany you home, my brother, as indeed will Kr̥ṣṇa.’*</l>
    5540</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Having spoken thus, Baladewa’s words were endorsed by the Yadu tribe.</l>
    .<l n="b">And treated thus, the prince’s heart blossomed like a lotus at the urging of gentle rain:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘Truly your words are fitting. May I, Your Majesty’s servant, continue to receive the special favour I have obtained!</l>
    .<l n="d">Indeed in your protection may I find the means by which my quest for virtue may succeed!’</l>
    5545</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">The Yadus were all happy to agree, none was averse to Arjuna’s presence,</l>
    .<l n="b">And welcomed the prince, as a guest, in every way he deserved.</l>
    .<l n="c">It would take too long to tell of this. Shortly after, as the sun set, the eighth hour* rang out.</l>
    .<l n="d">The radiant glow of the clouds, coloured brightly with beams of light like golden ornaments, gave way to night.</l>
    5550</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Lord Kr̥ṣṇa withdrew to his quarters, in company with the prince who loved him so.</l>
    .<l n="b">Their spirits were as one, their affection deep and so they moved off to his private suite there in the camp.</l>
    .<l n="c">Shortly afterwards peace descended on all the Yadu tribe and on Dhanañjaya.</l>
    .<l n="d">‘It is just as the mist reaches the waters of the ocean,’ he thought.</l>
    5555</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">Let us say no more of the kings but tell now of the palace ladies.</l>
    .<l n="b">They were teased by longing now that the waning moon had altered the appearance of the night.</l>
    .<l n="c">The stars moved away to hide, just as a distressed girl, with side-long glances, turns her face away.</l>
    .<l n="d">Geese in flight, distant specks in the sky, that seemed to be eloping together, came to alight on a beautiful pond.</l>
    5560</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Abandoned, despondent and melancholy, the bees waited in their holes, distressed now that they had been robbed of their desire,</l>
    .<l n="b">For the lotuses were no longer open. How cruel their actions,* for they were almost full-grown.</l>
    .<l n="c">Mournfully, the cuckoos lamented that the moon had not yet come to succour them in their love-sickness that evening,</l>
    .<l n="d">Forlorn and trembling because it was the ninth day of the dark half-month and the moon had not yet risen.</l>
    5565</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">Moreover, the distant thunder seemed to summon whispered verses close to their ears.</l>
    .<l n="b">The sighing breeze bearing sweet fragrance to them was like the secret messenger of one waiting to elope.</l>
    .<l n="c">Suddenly the moon shone down brightly, to reveal itself in its full glory, as it rose high over the mountain peak,</l>
    .<l n="d">As if delighted to look down on the beauty of the women, happily applying powder* in the inner court.</l>
    5570</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">How lovely they were as they adorned their hair-knots with <foreign>aśoka</foreign> and <foreign>sumanasa</foreign> flowers, happily putting on their ornaments.</l>
    .<l n="b">As they chatted together in the light of the moon, some were plaiting combs in their hair.</l>
    .<l n="c">Merely to speak of the pursuit of pleasure and the enjoyment of beauty, filled them with desire,</l>
    .<l n="d">And because of their unrestrained longing and their sweetness, the very sight of the moon swept them away with passion.</l>
    5575</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">These beautiful women were skilled at expressing a poet’s passionate love in allusions.</l>
    .<l n="b">It was only right that maidens so fair should not seek to hide the charm of their <foreign>salukat</foreign> playing in singing <foreign>kidung</foreign>.</l>
    .<l n="c">Because their skills were renowned throughout the land it seemed to enhance their sweetness as they accompanied themselves on the <foreign>kangsi</foreign>.</l>
    .<l n="d">And not only that, for in their lute playing, the beauty of the ocean of honey* came surging forth.</l>
    5580</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">The women enhanced their charm and beauty by all having mastered thoroughly the art of poetry,</l>
    .<l n="b">Their recitations became even more captivating, as the strummed lute accompanied* those sweet-voiced singers.</l>
    .<l n="c">Their playing seemed to be stolen liquid syrup and melted honey from a broken dish,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Mixed with moonbeams, so that their <foreign>gaməlan</foreign> playing caused utter enchantment.</l>
    5585</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">Others, filled with love, were talking quietly in sweet discussion.</l>
    .<l n="b">Such easy prey for the God of Love were they, that their hearts were the target of passionate desires.</l>
    .<l n="c">Her feelings of love leaving her weak,* one girl went to lie down with a <foreign>kakawin</foreign> scribbled on a pandanus leaf.</l>
    .<l n="d">As she read her poem aloud by the light of the moon, she was so painfully affected that in trying to keep secret* her longing, she fainted away.</l>
    5590</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="36">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Yet the one who held sway over the subtle form of fragrant beauty, a goddess of letters in human form,</l>
    .<l n="b">Was Subhadrā, the younger sister of Baladewa, now the fairest of maidens.</l>
    5595<l n="c">Indeed the beauty of this precious jewel of the palace was so renowned</l>
    .<l n="d">That the very incarnation of liquid honey would return to seek help from her charms.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The lovely women who lived in the royal palace were enchanting as they disported in the moonlight.</l>
    .<l n="b">With a deluge of charm, as they skilfully sang songs containing allusions and played <foreign>gaməlan</foreign>, they were indeed as beautiful as heavenly women.</l>
    5600<l n="c">For the princess alone, they always composed with great devotion, songs</l>
    .<l n="d">That were as lively and charming as the ocean overflowing with the rains of the fourth month.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Without doubt, these court maidens were truly possessed of the greatest sweetness,</l>
    .<l n="b">But the charms of the princess were without peer, she alone held beauty.</l>
    5605<l n="c">Just as the alluring lotus, opening up, reflects the glow of moonbeams,</l>
    .<l n="d">Her beauty was enhanced by her adornments and all who gazed upon it seemed to lose themselves in rapture.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">At the fourth stroke of midnight, the lovely women were still happily disporting there,</l>
    .<l n="b">But the princess, lulled by their <foreign>gaməlan</foreign> playing, had become sleepy.</l>
    5610<l n="c">A couch was arranged for her beneath a fragrant spreading <foreign>wungū</foreign> tree,</l>
    .<l n="d">Beautifully entwined with the shoots of the cinnamon tree and strewn on all sides was fragrant* jasmine.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">There the princess, as beautiful as the Goddess of Love, Ratih, rested on the bed.</l>
    .<l n="b">Soothed by her beautiful surroundings, sleepiness crept over her and entered unseen into her heart.</l>
    5615<l n="c">Blown about constantly by the wind, the boughs fluttered in the breeze, like waving fans.</l>
    .<l n="d">Soothingly and affectionately* the bees in their holes called out gently.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The delightful murmuring of the <foreign>garantung</foreign> bamboo xylophones delightfully vied, in unbroken rhythm, with the thunder.</l>
    .<l n="b">Lovely and sweet was the music of the lutes as the women gracefully and languidly sang the introductory melody,</l>
    5620<l n="c">As if to soothe and sing a lullaby to their lady, who slept there absorbed in dreams,</l>
    .<l n="d">For all the world like an offering of a maiden,* resting on a couch, inspiring devotion.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="37">
    5625<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The enchantment of the night permeated everywhere.</l>
    .<l n="b">Moreover, the distant splashing of a waterfall could be heard unceasingly.</l>
    .<l n="c">The hammering of bark* suddenly sounded out and seemed to inspire feelings of longing,</l>
    .<l n="d">As its relentless, incessant beat urged lovers to elope.</l>
    .</p>
    5630<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Thunder rumbled softly like a lover’s sweet whispers,</l>
    .<l n="b">To make the buds of the flowers of the <foreign>unəng</foreign> creeper* split open and display themselves in their fullness.</l>
    .<l n="c">The areca palm blossoms unfurled to wound the hearts of the love-lorn mercilessly,</l>
    .<l n="d">The <foreign>asanas,</foreign> buffeted by the wind, spread their fragrant perfume on the breeze.</l>
    .</p>
    5635<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Such was the beauty and charm that it would fain set hearts atremble.</l>
    .<l n="b">Pārtha was not yet asleep for he was completely captivated.</l>
    .<l n="c">A breath of wind passing by brought him its cool freshness.</l>
    .<l n="d">He could hear the <foreign>walik</foreign> calling, its lament made him smile.*</l>
    .</p>
    5640<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Night passed and as day dawned, the world donned fresh clothing,</l>
    .<l n="b">As the <foreign>asanas</foreign> in the borders of the delightful hermitage opened.</l>
    .<l n="c">The sun whirled, spinning around in the water of the sea, </l>
    .<l n="d">Its golden rays shining brightly to dye the heavens in red light.</l>
    .</p>
    5645<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Birds twittered* in the branches, merrily calling out* to each other for joy of the day.</l>
    .<l n="b">Swarming bees buzzed backwards and forwards, resting on one flower* after another, like husbands* going from wife to wife.</l>
    .<l n="c">When it became light, the son of Pāṇḍu bathed and purified himself</l>
    .<l n="d">Before invoking the sun with the recitation of mantras and the prescribed rites.*</l>
    .</p>
    5650<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Assiduously, he sought the object of his prayers.</l>
    .<l n="b">His heart ever turned to the gods as he performed his worship.</l>
    .<l n="c">So too, Lord Kr̥ṣṇa devoted himself to reciting the mantras of kingship,</l>
    .<l n="d">Unfailingly striving for tranquillity, and, having adorned himself, was even more resplendent.</l>
    .</p>
    5655<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">When they had both completed their ritual washing and recited their prayers,</l>
    .<l n="b">They came out together, standing ready there at the gateway.</l>
    .<l n="c">Their garments gleaming brightly shone like the newly-risen sun.</l>
    .<l n="d">Together, they were as resplendent as the sun riding on the highest point of the eastern mountain.</l>
    .</p>
    5660<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The Yadus were already assembled, their vassals all stood ready.</l>
    .<l n="b">Haladhara was bedecked with gleaming jewels.</l>
    .<l n="c">Incomparable was he, clearly a hero of immense presence.</l>
    .<l n="d">All the Wr̥ṣṇis and Andhakas stood together in rows in close formation.</l>
    .</p>
    5665<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Then they set out immediately, and came at last to the sanctuary,*</l>
    .<l n="b">Where all was faultlessly arranged, in great splendour.</l>
    .<l n="c">Standards fluttered gracefully on high,* a glittering mass,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Pennants swayed and pennons sparkled.*</l>
    .</p>
    5670<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">As the Yadu troops noisily bustled about their tasks there in the hermitage, they filled it completely.</l>
    .<l n="b">The melodies, sounding out unceasingly,* were taken up* by the many singers.</l>
    .<l n="c">Then, filling every direction, - north, south, east and west, - with their sound,</l>
    .<l n="d">Drums banged and gongs and <foreign>roñji</foreign>* answered each other.</l>
    .</p>
    5675<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">The commotion of so many Wr̥ṣṇis and Yadus became more and more tumultuous.</l>
    .<l n="b">They looked like an ocean of blossoming flowers in their brilliant festival attire, </l>
    .<l n="c">And it was especially the lovely women who created this beautiful scene,</l>
    .<l n="d">With the movement of their shapely eyebrows as sharp as slivers of gravel.*</l>
    .</p>
    5680</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="38">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The Yadu hosts added their increasing lustre to the radiance of the temple.</l>
    .<l n="b">It was as divine in appearance as the abode of the gods and its shrines were all-surpassing.</l>
    .<l n="c"> Exquisite cloths - <foreign>dukūla, manitra</foreign> and <foreign>kairatila* </foreign>- all decoratively arranged, were draped everywhere,</l>
    5685<l n="d">And, as if by magic, the garlands of <foreign>cawəli</foreign> silk seemed to be aflame.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Songs of praise* rang out and many different bells tinkled like buzzing bees circling beautiful flowers.</l>
    .<l n="b">All was enriched by the blaring of conches, vying with the resounding <foreign>gubar</foreign> gongs,</l>
    .<l n="c">As the chief priests softly and clearly recited prayers together,</l>
    5690<l n="d">For the prosperity of the kingdom, that it might be without conflict* and all evil-doers vanquished.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">After paying homage to the deities, the kings performed the flower-offering ceremonies at the shrine of Widhi.* </l>
    .<l n="b">The Yadus also all performed flower worship to Wiṣṇu, truly concentrating their thoughts upon him,*</l>
    .<l n="c">As he now descended to the most exquisite, golden pavilion,* for he was their paramount protector,</l>
    5695<l n="d">Renowned on earth as the cause of the king’s most famous deeds.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The festivities then took place, arranged with all-surpassing magnificence.</l>
    .<l n="b">Elated, the Yadus joined together in mock-combat, and moved into the attack, resplendently.*</l>
    .<l n="c">All who took part were skilled in the use of shields and in wielding javelins and hatchets.</l>
    5700<l n="d">Their gleaming armour seemed ablaze as wave after wave attacked, becoming ever more dazzling.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Some looked their opponents defiantly in the eye. All were masters at alternately pushing forward then dodging skilfully.</l>
    .<l n="b">Standing upright together they exchanged lusty shouts,* for they had been well trained in the ways of battle.</l>
    .<l n="c">In their splendour, they were worthy bearers* of the gleaming jackets of honour and sparkling arm-bands.*</l>
    5705<l n="d">The violence of their clashing drowned out* the constant roar of thundering <foreign>gubar</foreign> and <foreign>paḍahi</foreign> drums.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The decorations worn by those wild with drink were resplendent: their gleaming mail shone all the more fiercely.</l>
    .<l n="b">Their breasts all aglow from their clothes, some wore bright shining collars.</l>
    .<l n="c">With their arms stretched sideways, they took no notice of the actions of those who shouted at them.</l>
    5710<l n="d">The attendants asked to bring them drinks of welcome, stopped, embarrassed by their jabbering.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The spectators, the young gentlewomen and the children of the nobles who were famous for their goodness and refined manners,</l>
    .<l n="b">Though amused to see this, covered their lips with their hands demurely.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Truly enchanting were the brief glimpses of their sideways glances as they opened and closed their mouths in sweet laughter,</l>
    5715<l n="d">And it seemed the gathering place of honey would be eclipsed by their open lips, fresh and red.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">But we will not tell of them as, at sunset, it all came to an end.</l>
    .<l n="b">A great feast was then held by all the Yadus, in the centre of the arena.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Laid out in readiness were all the delicious produce of mountain, forest and sea,</l>
    5720<l n="d">Which they ate with relish, their enjoyment enhanced by the entertainment offered by the musicians.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Because it had been arranged by the kings, Kr̥ṣṇa, Pārtha, Baladewa and Ugrasena,</l>
    .<l n="b">There seemed to be a thundering mountain torrent* of meat, drink and other delicacies.</l>
    .<l n="c">The kings had catered for every conceivable taste,</l>
    5725<l n="d">And all became more and more intoxicated, overwhelmed with drinks of fermented spirits* and rum.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="39">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus was the form of the worship they performed,* most prominent amongst them* all the Wr̥ṣṇi heroes.</l>
    5730<l n="b">But we will not tell of this. After they had finished eating, all had been made content by the king’s bounty,</l>
    .<l n="c">Not to mention the Wr̥ṣṇi troops who were replete with food and drink.</l>
    .<l n="d">Becoming ever more joyful and merry, they took their leisure and caroused in their quarters.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">In the cool of the evening Baladewa went off in search of beauty.</l>
    5735<l n="b">Lord Kr̥ṣṇa following behind, they set off from the royal quarters.</l>
    .<l n="c">With Pārtha at his side, riding with him in the same chariot,</l>
    .<l n="d">Clearly they were indeed, as splendid as Wiṣṇu* and the God of Love, both irresistible in form.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The valiant Wr̥ṣṇis and Andhakas also went off to seek out different pleasures,* each according to their desire.</l>
    5740<l n="b">There were some who headed for the hermitage to reflect on the beauty of the banks of the river* and deep craggy gullies.</l>
    .<l n="c">Others went to secluded parts of the forest, in search of a place to be alone and gaze out over the distant ocean,</l>
    .<l n="d">While others went hunting, gaily cooking and eating [their catch in] a floating water-pavilion.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Even more magnificent was the princess as she departed,* indeed, she was a painting come to life.</l>
    5745<l n="b">Riding in a chariot on a throne of gold, she was as beautiful as the embodiment of all the deities of the month of spring,</l>
    .<l n="c">Displaying charms that seemed to come forth from the realm of dreams to thrust aside all other sensory delights.</l>
    .<l n="d">Her escort of warriors, standing fully-equipped on either side, was as resplendent as a foot-guard of gods. </l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The ladies of the court were like flower buds opening up, their joyful hearts full of high spirits.</l>
    5750<l n="b">Their attendants and handmaidens competed with each other to gather the largest bunches of blossoming flowers.</l>
    .<l n="c">Many rode in covered palanquins of gold, others in black ones with golden parasols,</l>
    .<l n="d">Which looked like bees in search of flowers, their colours muted* by a misty veil of fragrant, unfurling pandanus.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">As if to restrain their tendrils from longing* to capture the hearts of the people passing by,</l>
    5755<l n="b">The supple creepers, newly unfurling, languidly hung down, limp with desire.</l>
    .<l n="c">Lovingly, the lovely <foreign>sanggākaśa</foreign> creeper seemed to embrace the beautiful clusters of blossoms, filled with passion.</l>
    .<l n="d">Moreover so thick were its tendrils that the area around was cast in shadow and gave forth fragrance to accompany them.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Like an aigrette of gold, the <foreign>karṇikāra</foreign>, displaying the charm of its blossom for the first time, was radiant.</l>
    5760<l n="b">Its young leaves* moved restlessly, stretching out in all directions as if they had no desire for the fragrant <foreign>gaḍung.</foreign></l>
    .<l n="c">They seemed to sway continuously, shying away from the embrace of the young shoots growing along the ground.</l>
    .<l n="d">Dallying there was a wood-cock, flapping his wings, with his wife below, his constant companion.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Then the trees rustling with expectant pleasure* in the soft breeze</l>
    5765<l n="b">That brings with it the rain of the fourth month, were delighted to be visited by such beautiful love-sick maidens, and invited them to come near.</l>
    .<l n="c">The mango and mangosteen, <foreign>rambutan</foreign>, <foreign>wadara</foreign>,* <foreign>wuni</foreign>, and <foreign>paḍali</foreign> were heavily laden, their flowers and fruits all laid ready for them, </l>
    .<l n="d">And the maids, gathering the fruits of the trees along the many paths, were delightful.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">As they picnicked there, how enchanting they were. The astounding sight of such extraordinary beauty was sure to quicken the pulse,</l>
    5770<l n="b">For, in great delight, they had lifted their hems as they sought pleasure, enhancing their loveliness still more,</l>
    .<l n="c">Exposing their slender calves, that, as they peeped from underneath their <foreign>kains</foreign>, were like ivory pandanus flowers.</l>
    .<l n="d">It was only fitting that the sight of them would make the desire and passion of any lover catch in his throat,* overpower and destroy him.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">The forest, carpeted with flowers, rivalled the design of a palace, its blooms drawn up in floral battle formations everywhere.</l>
    5775<l n="b">The women were the female warriors* attacking them together, inevitably destroying them as they seized them.</l>
    .<l n="c">Indeed they were lions in battle, like bees thrusting eagerly, wanting only to be one* with the fragrant flowers.</l>
    .<l n="d">And so they all joined in laying waste the flowers,* carrying them off by force, plucking them all without pause.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">There were many whose thoughts had turned to love-making and, without further ado, they ornamented their beauty as they walked along.</l>
    5780<l n="b">Wholly unconstrained, they arranged tendrils of the <foreign>aśoka</foreign> as love-tokens* in their hair, the pollen enveloping them in its fragrance.</l>
    .<l n="c"><foreign>Śridanta</foreign> and <foreign>wungu</foreign> were the ornaments they used as sashes and necklaces delightfully adorning themselves.</l>
    .<l n="d">One could only surmise that in their beauty was the alluring sweetness of a sister to love* seeking out pleasure.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    5785<div type="canto" n="40">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">We will tell of Lord Kr̥ṣṇa and Pārtha,</l>
    .<l n="b">As in leisurely manner, they made their way along the mountain ridge,</l>
    .<l n="c">Looking down on the beauty of the hill below,</l>
    .<l n="d">Its charms clearly lying ready to view.</l>
    5790</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Pure, sparkling waters splashed down over the ravine,</l>
    .<l n="b">The many streams forming a pond of great beauty.</l>
    .<l n="c">The glistening water plants thus bespattered</l>
    .<l n="d">Were indeed like a treasure trove of countless jewels and gems there.</l>
    5795</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Another crystal-clear brook spilled down the hill.</l>
    .<l n="b">A waterfall could be distinctly heard tumbling straight down into the ravine.</l>
    .<l n="c">There in the deep gully it roared like thunder,</l>
    .<l n="d">Resounding more loudly than the <foreign>gubar</foreign> and <foreign>gəṇḍing</foreign> drums at the great festival.</l>
    5800</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Moreover its sparkling, glinting droplets</l>
    .<l n="b">Were scattered and strewn about on every side,</l>
    .<l n="c">As if to bid them welcome with reverential salutations </l>
    .<l n="d">Constantly* paying them homage, or so they thought.</l>
    5805</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Lord Arjuna was delighted when he saw</l>
    .<l n="b">How the mountain seemed to hold itself in readiness.</l>
    .<l n="c">Peacocks crowed on the hills along the mountain ridges</l>
    .<l n="d">And the <foreign>kamanak</foreign>* together answered each other.</l>
    5810</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The soft buzzing of bees, charmingly lost in contemplation of beautiful flowers,</l>
    .<l n="b">Could be heard all along the path, </l>
    .<l n="c">Sipping nectar like priests</l>
    .<l n="d">Conferring blessings of praise on the two of them as they passed.</l>
    5815</p>
