    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Moreover, the casuarinas blowing about in the wind, rustled,</l>
    .<l n="b">Whispering gently as if to attract their attention.</l>
    .<l n="c">Faintly, softly, the turtle doves provided the accompaniment</l>
    .<l n="d">In counterpoint to the melodious voices of the <foreign>pakṣi kətur</foreign> birds.</l>
    5820</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">The shoots of the <foreign>wəlas-hyun</foreign> creeper were beautifully intertwined*</l>
    .<l n="b">With the fragrant palms,* quite inseparable.</l>
    .<l n="c">The widely spread branches of the trees hung low,</l>
    .<l n="d">And the water lilies, from kindness, seemed to keep them afloat.*</l>
    5825</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Moreover, there was over-hanging <foreign>prabhu sanmata</foreign> there, </l>
    .<l n="b">With its creepers unfurling on all sides to screen* the thickets.</l>
    .<l n="c">Charmingly showing itself in its full richness, the ripened <foreign>wuni</foreign> </l>
    .<l n="d">Skilfully split its sharp blackened points into four.</l>
    5830</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Mount Raiwata[ka] was truly beautiful</l>
    .<l n="b">And Janārdana spoke of it thus:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘Here is the fixed abode* of God Wiṣṇu,</l>
    .<l n="d">None other than the place of refuge of the people of Dwārawatī.</l>
    5835</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">‘The Yadus therefore always strive</l>
    .<l n="b">To ensure that proper worship flourishes and respectfully pay homage here,</l>
    .<l n="c">Sedulously intent on their aim of furthering the welfare of the realm,</l>
    .<l n="d">And from its protection comes its certain prosperity.’</l>
    5840</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Thus said Kr̥ṣṇa to Dhanañjaya,</l>
    .<l n="b">Filling the prince’s heart with strength.</l>
    .<l n="c">Therefore he set off happily</l>
    .<l n="d">Along the winding valley path through the ravine.</l>
    5845</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">The dense bamboo that lined the narrow path,</l>
    .<l n="b">Was shaken and bent back by the gentle breeze.</l>
    .<l n="c">The plants had deliberately opened up to expose their centres</l>
    .<l n="d">And when they were pushed over, they seemed to sink down with a rustle.</l>
    5850</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Steep slopes and precipices came right up to the verges. </l>
    .<l n="b"><foreign>Gəsing</foreign> and <foreign>pətung</foreign> bamboos rose up side by side,</l>
    .<l n="c">Sheaths unfurled to expose their half-closed eyes, blinking</l>
    .<l n="d">Their scratchy shoots,* all ready for the attack.</l>
    5855</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">It would take too long to tell of them passing by the thickets.</l>
    .<l n="b">With each step they encountered beauty.</l>
    .<l n="c">As they gazed up at the mountain, its splendour seemed magical,</l>
    .<l n="d">Its charm as a pleasure spot quite unsurpassed.</l>
    5860</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="41">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">They could see the women of the inner court enjoying the scenery there, all as beautiful as figures in a painting.</l>
    .<l n="b">As they delightfully cut flower-sprays, displaying their charms anew,* how resplendent they were.</l>
    5865<l n="c">They looked like sculpted diamonds as they abandoned themselves to the pursuit of pleasure all joyfully disporting, themselves,</l>
    .<l n="d">Their charms those of the Goddess of Beauty herself, newly emerging in bodily form from a profusion of flowers.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">A garden of beautiful women were they, akin to <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers that have just come to intimate union* with the river.</l>
    .<l n="b">Some were adorning themselves, looking at their reflections in the water whilst arranging their hair-knots with bouquets of flowers.</l>
    5870<l n="c">Others dangled their legs in the water to cool themselves, as if to avoid* the gushing torrent,</l>
    .<l n="d">Attractively exposing their slender waists, fit to pierce the <foreign>kangsi</foreign>* of the God of Love.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">These beautiful ladies were like a painting come to life, their glances, when they looked sideways, sweet enough</l>
    .<l n="b">To cause intense love-pangs and burning desire. Their hair bands were as perfect and smooth as dark clouds.</l>
    5875<l n="c">Their graceful limbs were bedecked with armlets and garlands made from <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers and <foreign>wəlas-harəp</foreign> creepers,</l>
    .<l n="d">Like a collection of beauty created by the God of Love, glimpsed for but a moment of passion, by a poet.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">One girl, lost in rapt contemplation of* the far ocean, would awaken feelings of love</l>
    .<l n="b">As if, at the decree of the Muse, her loveliness was not of this world, but must merge into the letters [of a poem].</l>
    5880<l n="c">Unperturbed as her waist broke free of the embrace of its bands, and suddenly loosened,</l>
    .<l n="d">To expose [her breasts] like ivory coconuts a little, she was enough to inundate* even the senses of an ascetic who has already attained detachment.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Another there was whose refined beauty was so like that of the <foreign>campaka</foreign> flower that it was only proper she be reserved for the God of Love.</l>
    .<l n="b">As she held on her lap a pandanus flower, her calves seemed driven to expose themselves as if they were the reason for the rain.</l>
    5885<l n="c">How beautiful she was as she wrote on the doll of petals cradled in her lap, inscribing it with her sharp nails,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Sitting restfully leaning on one arm on the rock, then turning her attention to the beauties of nature in the stream in the gully.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Yet another rested charmingly on a couch of rock as she pictured in her mind the petal-doll coming to life.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Fragrant leaves and jasmine were her mattress as she sat absorbed in the vastness* of the beautiful sky.</l>
    5890<l n="c">Her skin was golden, her uncovered waist as supple as the new shoots of the <foreign>aśoka,</foreign></l>
    .<l n="d">Which would clearly wither, if she were approached on that couch by an ardent lover.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The beautiful female attendants transported beauty there, as they amused themselves, their charms surpassing* those of flower buds.</l>
    .<l n="b">Exuberantly they sought sweet delight. All had been blessed with figures of such beauty that they were fitting to be the object of longing.</l>
    5895<l n="c">Joyously the young girls, wearing beautiful wreaths of <foreign>wungū</foreign> flowers, picked flowers and shoots,</l>
    .<l n="d">Their youthful sweetness giving them a special radiance as they moved about. </l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">They seemed never to tire of seeking out the beauties of nature, spreading out* the fragrant <foreign>asanas</foreign> and jasmine.</l>
    .<l n="b">They wove blossoming <foreign>tañjung</foreign> and lovely <foreign>priyaka</foreign> into garlands and used them straight away as pins in their hair-knots.</l>
    5900<l n="c">Their ear ornaments were young <foreign>tarawarṣa</foreign> creepers,* their hair secured with clasps of <foreign>gaḍung</foreign> shoots,*</l>
    .<l n="d">The fragrant pollen which fell on their beautiful breasts, they used as powder, its perfumes wafting overall.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Although the many beautiful women there could be depicted as incarnations of Beauty,</l>
    .<l n="b">They were clearly no match for the sweet beauty of her whose loveliness outshone* all at court.</l>
    5905<l n="c">Instead, if they entered her presence, the charms of these other jewels of the palace seemed to become useless and falter.</l>
    .<l n="d">In short, Subhadrā was the essence of beauty* and the incarnation of every delight of the ocean of honey.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Now Nature had fashioned a bower that was as beautiful as a painting.</l>
    .<l n="b">Carved of coral, beautifully hung with curtains of <foreign>wəlas-harəp</foreign> creeper, gracefully it displayed its charms.</l>
    5910<l n="c">Forming a magnificent wall along each side, <foreign>jangga</foreign> vines unfurled towards the sugar palms.</l>
    .<l n="d">As they reached out, shaken continually by the wind, their wafted fragrance pervaded overall.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">From there, she took pleasure in watching her maids who had mastered thoroughly the art of beautiful songs.</l>
    .<l n="b">She was like a beautiful statue, lost in thought, and they came to her to present her with fragrant pandanus<foreign>.</foreign></l>
    5915<l n="c">Such was her due and, undoubtedly, she alone was the most exalted jewel of the court.</l>
    .<l n="d">How else could she be thought of than as the beauty of molten honey in visible form?</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Truly, she was the origin* of bounteous beauty, the jewel of loveliness, the soul of the whole world.</l>
    .<l n="b">Confused, the bees in the pandanus followed after her, carried away by longing, unable to resist caressing her feet.</l>
    5920<l n="c">Those devoted* to her care could not fail to be thrown into confusion at the sight of her resting there on the elephant rock.</l>
    .<l n="d">Any who caught even a glimpse of her would think that she was the goddess of beauty, returning to her immaterial state.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">How could the beauty of the seeds of the <foreign>sumanasa</foreign>* or the blossoming pandanus not be defeated and annihilated?</l>
    .<l n="b">How could even the most skilfully written <foreign>kakawin</foreign> possibly have within its orbit the words to depict* her?</l>
    5925<l n="c">The sharp point of the stylus of a poet composing verse would snap,* unable to go on, greatly distressed and without purpose,</l>
    .<l n="d">Because in the face of her beauty, the subtle words on the writing board would cease, their blackness would simply vanish.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">The delights of the sea-shore would be destroyed, so awe-stricken at being thus rejected,* that they would leave without a backward glance.</l>
    .<l n="b">The mountains would crumble, not daring to breathe, no longer able to elicit rapturous wonder because of her.</l>
    5930<l n="c">Taken by surprise, the beauty of the sky, even if it could be captured,* would certainly have no effect and would pine away,</l>
    .<l n="d">While the charms of a beautiful garden would disappear, even though it would wrongly cause sorrow.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="42">
    5935<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Pārtha came there together with Kr̥ṣṇa,</l>
    .<l n="b">Their hearts filled with joy at seeing the beauty of the wooded hills.</l>
    .<l n="c">All at once Pārtha was overcome with sharp longing.</l>
    .<l n="d">Thoughts of the princess filled his mind, throwing him into utter confusion.</l>
    .</p>
    5940<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Therefore the prince questioned the king:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘That girl there, Subhadrā, who is known to be the most outstanding of princesses,</l>
    .<l n="c">Goddess of all enchanting beauty, </l>
    .<l n="d">The daughter of king Basudewa, is a jewel amongst maidens.</l>
    .</p>
    5945<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘Truly, on all this earth she has no equal.</l>
    .<l n="b">How could any passionate man* be indifferent to her or unaffected by her?</l>
    .<l n="c">Beauty* should be the only goal of a passionate man.</l>
    .<l n="d">Gold and superb jewels would easily be a fitting price for it.’</l>
    .</p>
    5950<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Thus he said. Kr̥ṣṇa replied:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘O indeed you are mistaken in what you say, my brother.</l>
    .<l n="c">Although my little sister is young and ripe for marriage,</l>
    .<l n="d">It is actually very difficult to find someone to match her.</l>
    .</p>
    5955<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘Even though it is expected* that a <foreign>swayambara</foreign> be held,</l>
    .<l n="b">Only forcible abduction would suffice,</l>
    .<l n="c">For a truly valiant and mighty hero </l>
    .<l n="d">Who would dare to seize her, unafraid of my presence here.</l>
    .</p>
    5960<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Perhaps such a one could win over my sister,</l>
    .<l n="b">And would not be afraid to resist the warriors of the line of Wr̥ṣṇi.’</l>
    .<l n="c">Thus said Janārdana with asperity,*</l>
    .<l n="d">As if inflamed with ire at the words of the son of Pāṇḍu.</l>
    .</p>
    5965<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The noble Pārtha was indeed resolute and knew no fear:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘Were all of them able to lie in ambush, still I would crush them and destroy them all!’</l>
    .<l n="c">Thus he thought and rose to his feet crying:</l>
    .<l n="d">‘I am not afraid of you Yadus!’ and immediately strode forward.</l>
    .</p>
    5970<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Swiftly he seized the frightened princess,</l>
    .<l n="b">Who was dazed and shocked as he clasped her to his breast,</l>
    .<l n="c">And climbed into his chariot, holding her so tightly in his embrace, that, in her terror, she was powerless to resist.</l>
    .<l n="d">With that he carried her off, speeding quickly away.</l>
    .</p>
    5975<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Thereupon the Yadus were filled with dejection, </l>
    .<l n="b">All sadly oppressed, that he was not intimidated.</l>
    .<l n="c">Despondently reflecting on their uselessness,</l>
    .<l n="d">For so contemptible were they that they had just stayed their hand and allowed him to go.</l>
    .</p>
    5980</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="43">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">We will not tell of Arjuna but of the Wr̥ṣṇis who fled</l>
    .<l n="b">To bow down* before Lord Haladhara and give news of Pārtha’s deed.</l>
    .<l n="c">The king was then so filled with boiling, righteous rage, </l>
    5985<l n="d">That sparks seem to fly from the reflected glare of his livid face.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">At once, in the heat of his blazing anger, he roared loudly:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘Shame upon you, O wicked, vile Pārtha! Believe that I will see that you are destroyed and swept away!’</l>
    .<l n="c">Thus said the king rising to his feet and seizing his great and powerful weapons,*</l>
    5990<l n="d">Looking more and more as if he would destroy the world and overturn the ocean, Rudra’s fire* in visible form.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">All the princes and particularly the kings were equally angry and eager to do battle.</l>
    .<l n="b">Moreover, all were very fierce and in their frenzy stood upright, like lions filled with fighting spirit.</l>
    .<l n="c">Pradyumna and Gadā, Satyaka, Niśaṭha and Sāmba, vehement and savage.</l>
    5995<l n="d">All possessed of tremendous great power, thorns in the side of any lion-like warrior were they.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">And the Wr̥ṣṇis, their valiant allies, were all celebrated for their skill,</l>
    .<l n="b">They too were indomitable champions, victorious in battle, skilful, resolute and famed.</l>
    .<l n="c">How could either advancing demon or monster not be pulverised?</l>
    6000<l n="d">Such was the extent of their uncontrolled anger that they ground their teeth with pent-up rage, and shouted out noisily to each other.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">It seemed that Mount Raiwata[ka] would surely be destroyed: the small animals were thrown into great commotion by the blaring of war trumpets,</l>
    .<l n="b">The thundering of the kettle-drums and the crashing of cymbals* all sounding out together.</l>
    .<l n="c">Elephants trumpeted, horses neighed, shouts rang out,</l>
    6005<l n="d">A kaleidoscope of multi-coloured standards rose on high, a dense mass of weapons glinting everywhere.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The hosts of warriors, with their entire forces, were fully equipped, all perfect in form.</l>
    .<l n="b">Valour lapped at their full hearts* like the ocean at the incoming tide.</l>
    .<l n="c">After being ordered into their respective divisions, they stood in formation to march out against Pārtha with all their might, </l>
    6010<l n="d">All equally impatient, voraciously wishing to prove how eager and unafraid they were.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Brimful with ferocity, the Yadus were fearful to behold, all shouting loudly,</l>
    .<l n="b">With but a single thought: to hunt Pārtha down, leaving no stone unturned, and kill him.</l>
    .<l n="c">They took up their many bows and weapons in readiness,</l>
    6015<l n="d">As frenzied as the Lord of Death in their great haste to attack furiously.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">With Haladhara’s departure, these heroes set out with a great roar. The troops advanced</l>
    .<l n="b">In serried ranks, in thundering, unbroken succession, as they tried to outpace each other,</l>
    .<l n="c">But as they came upon Lord Kr̥ṣṇa, who was quite unperturbed, they came to a halt,</l>
    6020<l n="d">Lord Haladhara choking to see his brother, the king, like that.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">He stepped forward quickly towards Lord Kr̥ṣṇa saying:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘O my brother! Fie! Do you mean to do nothing about Pārtha’s evil conduct!</l>
    .<l n="c">We can no longer regard him as a brother! It is not to be contemplated!</l>
    6025<l n="d">In vain we have treated him with honour and entertained him regally.*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘Indeed, I perceive his insult as so extreme that I am roused to anger by it.</l>
    .<l n="b">In truth, he is despicable! How can he act in such an evil, hostile, vile manner?</l>
    .<l n="c">Truly he knows not the meaning of respect as set down in the Law. He shows us nothing but scorn in abducting our sister.*</l>
    6030<l n="d">Blind to proper conduct, treacherous, his insolence goes too far, he has insulted us beyond measure.’*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">Thus he said harshly and Lord Kr̥ṣṇa answered him:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘O King such vehement talk avails you nothing!</l>
    .<l n="c">You are a hero,* a world-protector, your victories are worthy of praise that resounds throughout the three worlds.</l>
    6035<l n="d">The depth of your power is truly an ocean, renowned for its great depths.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="44">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘Here is the highest truth to which you should adhere.</l>
    6040<l n="b">It is proper that a learned man of the world be accomplished in virtue.</l>
    .<l n="c">He should not half-heartedly seek discernment,</l>
    .<l n="d">So that he may have mastery over both subtle and obvious* truth.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘You must always consider the existence of enemies and friends,</l>
    6045<l n="b">Who are both seen and unseen. </l>
    .<l n="c">It is their nature to oppose* good</l>
    .<l n="d">And therefore well-being is generated.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘You are the irreproachable ruler of the world.</l>
    6050<l n="b">Never do you show the least lack of discretion.</l>
    .<l n="c">Like a fire blazing fierce and bright,</l>
    .<l n="d">You are ever ready to vanquish any stain.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘You are as inviolable as the water of life,</l>
    6055<l n="b">Sweeping before it the activities of the impure mind.</l>
    .<l n="c">Living rightfully, observing right conduct, pure in body,</l>
    .<l n="d">You are the authority* of all law.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘This is why I urge you to be calm.</l>
    6060<l n="b">Only the despicable treat their king with contempt.</l>
    .<l n="c">You say Dhanañjaya has insulted you,</l>
    .<l n="d">But, on the contrary, I believe he has shown us the greatest honour.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘Consider this O king! Is it proper for a virtuous man to think</l>
    6065<l n="b">That a wife should be bought for valuables -</l>
    .<l n="c">For jewels, precious stones, gold and so on?</l>
    .<l n="d">To do so would be to consider her no better than cattle, a base and miserable thought.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘Where in this world would you find an honourable man who would deliberately seek</l>
    6070<l n="b">To sell his marriageable daughter willingly?</l>
    .<l n="c">For this reason the <foreign>swayambara</foreign>, or bride’s choice is approved.</l>
    .<l n="d">If a man does not attend to this, he neglects his duty to the world.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘But see, we have not yet performed</l>
    6075<l n="b">This ceremony that accords with the highest <foreign>dharma</foreign>.</l>
    .<l n="c">And this is the reason for Dhanañjaya’s conduct.</l>
    .<l n="d">This abduction is not wrong but most excellent.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘For he has obviously relied on his valorous might,</l>
    6080<l n="b">And displayed his irresistible presence.</l>
    .<l n="c">He has been able to abduct Subhadrā</l>
    .<l n="d">With such confidence by virtue of his prowess.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    6085<div type="canto" n="45">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘Your Majesty, in my opinion, to use force against him would be wrong and to no avail,</l>
    .<l n="b">For we have already clearly seen how he gained the victory at a <foreign>swayambara</foreign> in the past.</l>
    .<l n="c">Even so, if put to the test, there is every chance he would prevail,</l>
    .<l n="d">For there is not a man* powerful enough to challenge his powers, not even Surapati.*</l>
    6090</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘Your glory as a world conqueror is already renowned.</l>
    .<l n="b">If he defeated you in battle you would be put to shame.</l>
    .<l n="c">In short, I must insist that the best course would be not to become enraged.</l>
    .<l n="d">You should only adhere to meritorious conduct, for such is the sole aim of a ruler who cares for the welfare of others.</l>
    6095</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘Now here is a course of action that may bring you a felicitous result, Your Majesty.</l>
    .<l n="b">Do not hesitate* to send an envoy to invite Dhanañjaya here now, quickly,</l>
    .<l n="c">Thereafter* to be married with all appropriate ceremonies. Do not fail to exert yourself in this,</l>
    .<l n="d">So that you may benefit from an alliance with all the Pāṇḍawas through such close family ties.</l>
    6100</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘My* heart is true and has never been otherwise.</l>
    .<l n="b">These were the reasons I may have seemed indifferent and unmoved, to have paid no mind and to have taken no action.’</l>
    .<l n="c">Thus said Kr̥ṣṇa and the Yadus acquiesced,</l>
    .<l n="d">Their burning fury extinguished like fire as the life-giving water of the king’s words showered down upon them.</l>
    6105</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Because of Kr̥ṣṇa’s intervention, Lord Baladewa now became calm.</l>
    .<l n="b">And so they halted and finally lay down all their arrows and weapons,</l>
    .<l n="c">Immediately preparing to invite the prince to come,</l>
    .<l n="d">With the delightful sound of the merry <foreign>gəṇḍings</foreign> heralding their departure.</l>
    6110</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Amidst great splendour, the princes set out with their followers,</l>
    .<l n="b">The noble widows* in particular competing to fill the chariots and elephants.</l>
    .<l n="c">The tramp of the many feet of that vast procession made a violent and tumultuous noise like a waterfall.*</l>
    .<l n="d">In their fine adornments this entourage was indeed like a forest of trees in blossom, as they delightfully walked along.</l>
    6115</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The many colourful banners side by side were a delight to behold,</l>
    .<l n="b">A resplendent rainbow arching down into budding flowers.</l>
    .<l n="c">Like mighty rock formations* were the lines of chariots, elephants and horses.</l>
    .<l n="d">The spaces between those walking along were deep ravines, and so crowded together were they, that progress became increasingly difficult.</l>
    6120</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">We will not tell of them on their journey, but will tell of Prince Pārtha.</l>
    .<l n="b">He travelled slowly, embracing the beautiful princess in her unceasing despair.</l>
    .<l n="c">As she called more and more loudly upon all the Yadus.</l>
    .<l n="d">It seemed she would die, as she sighed plaintively on his lap, swooning, completely overwhelmed.</l>
    6125</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">She became distraught at the sweetness of his endearments:</l>
    .<l n="b">‘My jewel, my darling! Resign yourself. How could you go back now?</l>
    .<l n="c">What a pity it is that now I hold you in the palm of my hand, you think constantly of escaping!</l>
    .<l n="d">Let your mind be easy, my dear. It is the fruits of our former existence that we now reap, as I carry you off.</l>
    6130</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘Clearly now I have found you, my precious jewel, dearest maiden,</l>
    .<l n="b">It is proper that your charms be the provisions for my journey as I seek the courage to perform deeds of valour.</l>
    .<l n="c">I am resolved if beset by enemies to show no fear:</l>
    .<l n="d">Indeed I am determined to meet in battle any who might come.</l>
    6135</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">‘Regard the strength of my arms as the bride-price I must pay for you.</l>
    .<l n="b">In truth, you will be the witness to my heroic deeds, my dear.’</l>
    .<l n="c">Thus said Pārtha with affection, addressing her with words of endearment, </l>
    .<l n="d">But the intensity of her tears only increased as she warded him off, moaning piteously. </l>
    6140</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Thus, he tried in so many ways to console* the confused and suffering girl.</l>
    .<l n="b">The Yadu hosts who had been sent to invite him to return, then came upon them,</l>
    .<l n="c">Bringing with them all the ritual gifts that could be desired of such a meeting.</l>
    .<l n="d">All were presented for the prince’s delight as they came forward to pay homage to him.</l>
    6145</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">‘My friend, His Majesty, the King asks that you return to him,</l>
    .<l n="b">The lady, too, should accompany you. Come back together now to the palace.</l>
    .<l n="c">For His Majesty is truly pleased to invite you there.</l>
    .<l n="d">His nature* is as sweet as the sugar palm entwined by the <foreign>gaḍung</foreign>.’</l>
    6150</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="14"><l n="a">Thus said all the princes, delighting Arjuna.</l>
    .<l n="b">Soon after, as the sun went down, they were escorted home.</l>
    .<l n="c">Riding in a black palanquin* closely surrounded by the throngs, they were as magnificent</l>
    .<l n="d">As the incomparable Śiwa and his consort descended to earth.</l>
    6155</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="15"><l n="a">Lord Kr̥ṣṇa and Haladhara were in the court-yard,</l>
    .<l n="b">Together with the royal consorts, all of equal beauty, awaiting them as they drew near.</l>
    .<l n="c">In the glow of the many torches, it was as bright as day.</l>
    .<l n="d">The whispering music of bamboo xylophones echoed, as if to proclaim the happiness of the whole kingdom.</l>
    6160</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="16"><l n="a">With his princess by his side, Dhanañjaya came forward</l>
    .<l n="b">And bowed low at the feet of both kings gathered there.</l>
    .<l n="c">At this, King Baladewa’s displeasure ceased, as he joyously received them warmly. </l>
    .<l n="d">Thus Kr̥ṣṇa’s noble teaching was brought to perfect fruition.</l>
    6165</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="17"><l n="a">After that, the kings dispatched a messenger to return to the palace compound,</l>
    .<l n="b">There, at the feet of King Basudewa,* to tell of the course of events.</l>
    .<l n="c">We will not tell of his journey but again tell of Phalguṇa,</l>
    .<l n="d">Joining in celebration with the Yadu tribe in their camp.</l>
    6170</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="18"><l n="a">In full measure, they regaled the prince in every way possible.</l>
    .<l n="b">Many kinds of delicious food and drinks had been prepared and were set before him.</l>
    .<l n="c">The friendship of King Harimūrti as well was undiminished,</l>
    .<l n="d">For it was his nature to act rightfully* and he was always dear to all.</l>
    6175</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="19"><l n="a">We will not tell of the time spent entertaining Pārtha.</l>
    .<l n="b">Night came and soon the whole kingdom slept.</l>
    .<l n="c">As night ended and day came, all arose</l>
    .<l n="d">And the kings went home, accompanied by the entire Yadu tribe.</l>
    6180</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="20"><l n="a">The noble Pārtha and the princess were escorted</l>
    .<l n="b">There to Dwārawatī, where they were indeed* received kindly by His Majesty the King.</l>
    .<l n="c">So it was that the joining of hands, religious observances, prayers and wedding ceremonies could then be performed,</l>
    .<l n="d">In accordance with the wishes expressed by Lord Kr̥ṣṇa.</l>
    6185</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="46">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Many spectators came to welcome the arrival of the Yadus to the city,</l>
    .<l n="b">All wanting to catch their first glimpse of this excellent prince of whom they had heard.</l>
    6190<l n="c">Because they had never seen him before, they had come immediately, running outside in great haste.</l>
    .<l n="d">Young and old, even widows waited, some so decrepit with age they were bent over, but who, nevertheless, wanted to go too.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">In a flurry, they came running quickly there. Some shouted out aloud in their desire to be first,</l>
    .<l n="b">Pushing against each other, bumping together, others racing neck and neck, called out noisily to those who had not come to the great square.</l>
    6195<l n="c">Heedless of their ornaments, many fought to be the first to catch sight of the prince,</l>
    .<l n="d">Others who had been adjusting their <foreign>kains</foreign> ran out, so anxious to fly there without delay, that they were left half-dressed.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Let us pass over the arrival of Dhanañjaya. The kings made their way towards the inner apartments.</l>
    .<l n="b">There, according to rank, they prostrated themselves at the feet of King Basudewa and his queen,</l>
    6200<l n="c">Who swiftly and kindly accepted Dhanañjaya, for not only was he handsome but he was also a powerful hero, possessed of virtue and skill,</l>
    .<l n="d">Moreover, a fitting partner for the princess, for he was none other than her close relative.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The King spoke thus, ‘Oh my son, Pārtha, hear what I have to say to you.</l>
    .<l n="b">Truly, just as Harimūrti and Karṣana,* you too are my refuge.</l>
    6205<l n="c">May it bring us prosperity, my son, to be united with you and to be of one purpose, without discord.*</l>
    .<l n="d">For we are the branches of one family. Do not forget that you too can be said to be of my own seed.’*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">The words of the king were sincere and, like ambrosia, brought contentment to those who heard them.</l>
    .<l n="b">Moreover, they were truly worthy sentiments, for he was an ancient and wise king, versed in the esoteric doctrines and practices of the welfare of others.</l>
    6210<l n="c">The prince thus addressed with words of honour, made an obeisance to acknowledge the felicity of the king’s words,</l>
    .<l n="d">Bringing great pleasure to the depths of the hearts of the hosts of soldiers who listened with delight to this praise.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="47">
    6215<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">After they had discoursed thus, the most eminent officials were appointed</l>
    .<l n="b">To arrange all that was needed for the performance of the <foreign>piḍuḍukan</foreign> ceremonies* and wedding offerings,</l>
    .<l n="c">Because the most auspicious time for the princess to be united in marriage with Dhanañjaya</l>
    .<l n="d">Was the following day, and it was then that they would receive the king’s blessing.*</l>
    .</p>
    6220<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">So* the entire Yadu tribe assembled there in complete formation and stood ready in the hall.</l>
    .<l n="b">The rank and file from throughout the land were there, drawn up in their various divisions, </l>
    .<l n="c">Ready to attend quickly to the king’s instructions,</l>
    .<l n="d">All firmly resolved to carry them out according to the prescriptions so that its splendour should be without flaw.</l>
    .</p>
    6225<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">And so all was arranged appropriately: the many offerings stood ready,</l>
    .<l n="b">Brought into being by the power of the king who was the supreme and excellent Wiṣṇu.</l>
    .<l n="c">Moreover, the buildings both inside and outside the palace,</l>
    .<l n="d">Were restored to their original perfect state, all richly and lavishly decorated.</l>
    .</p>
    6230<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The open hall, beautifully roofed with a canopy of lovely jewels, sparkled.</l>
    .<l n="b">Of equal splendour were the pillars carved with different designs.</l>
    .<l n="c">Moreover, the bamboo leaves that glittered along the gleaming fences </l>
    .<l n="d">Were painted with plant motifs* that looked like masked figures.</l>
    .</p>
    6235<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Even the ridges of the roof were exquisite, inlaid with patterns of precious stones.</l>
    .<l n="b">The galleries along the sides, surrounded by screens, were shaped like the fins of fishes.*</l>
    .<l n="c">Gleaming,* golden <foreign>jangga</foreign> vines* trailed delicately over the panels.</l>
    .<l n="d">Set with rubies, the <foreign>cawəni</foreign> muslin had embroidered leaf-designs of shining embroidered silk.</l>
    .</p>
    6240<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The land now reverberated like the crashing ocean,</l>
    .<l n="b">As the music of the <foreign>mr̥dangga</foreign> and <foreign>paḍahi</foreign> royal drums thundered out in unison,</l>
    .<l n="c">And the great celebrations and feasting that the Yadus held</l>
    .<l n="d">Were now directed towards the preparations for the marriage celebration* of the noble Phalguṇa.</l>
    .</p>
    6245<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">Ugrasena had arrived in the court-yard together with the other kings,</l>
    .<l n="b">Prominent amongst them was Harimūrti, their leader, and Halāyudha.</l>
    .<l n="c">As Prince Pārtha was regaled magnificently in the hall,</l>
    .<l n="d">All thought he surpassed even Surapati in splendour.</l>
    .</p>
    6250<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">There was a beautiful bower of love, of unrivalled magnificence,</l>
    .<l n="b">A creation of the God of Love himself, a building of diamonds, beautifully arranged for the pleasure of passionate lovers.</l>
    .<l n="c">Its roof was set with glittering, blue <foreign>śaśarudhira</foreign> gems and an orb of sparkling rubies.</l>
    .<l n="d">Its embroidered canopy was shaped like the moon and embroidered with* <foreign>cucur</foreign> birds.</l>
    .</p>
    6255<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">There was a balcony on the high ledge of the front verandah* of this pavilion.</l>
    .<l n="b">All the beauty of the Tāladhwaja* garden unfolding in the fourth month, had assembled there.</l>
    .<l n="c">Spread out were <foreign>kalpataru</foreign> flowers,* prepared as ornaments for the bower.</l>
    .<l n="d">The fragrance of burning incense inspired pangs of love as it diffused its delightful fragrance without cease.</l>
    .</p>
    6260<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">Inside the princess was being attended*..............</l></p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">.......The religious rites had been performed and all was set ready</l>
    .<l n="b">For the reverential salutations, auspicious ceremonies and acts of worship in the presence of the kings.</l></p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="12"><l n="a">Many glorious prayers of offering were recited there.</l>
    .<l n="b">The music of the <foreign>paḍahi</foreign> drums for their entertainment and the singing too, were delightful.</l>
    6265<l n="c">As night fell, this most excellent scene was suddenly bedecked in new raiment,</l>
    .<l n="d">From the bright glow of lighted lamps, like an assembly of suns.</l></p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="13"><l n="a">We will not tell of this. After the completion of the wedding* ceremony, the bridal couple</l>
    .<l n="b">Came back and moved to their palanquin, like flower buds inundated by rain.</l>
    .<l n="c">To the accompaniment of the lovely <foreign>gaməlan</foreign>, sweet and soft, they set off.</l>
    6270<l n="d">The tramp of the people escorting them sounding like the rumbling thunder that always accompanies the month of spring.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="48">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">They went up into the sapphire bower where they were to join* in sexual union.</l>
    6275<l n="b">How enchanting was its beauty, its covers perfumed with the seven fragrances* and scented with fragrant saffron.</l>
    .<l n="c">The aroma of camphor and the perfume of the <foreign>jənu</foreign> were a call to love-making</l>
    .<l n="d">Clearly awakening longing in the hearts of questing* lovers and bringing them pangs of love.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Within there, Pārtha, enraptured, held the princess on his lap.</l>
    6280<l n="b">Moreover, the whispered urgings of the God of Love aroused him and filled his being with desire.</l>
    .<l n="c">He was overcome with the confusion of unrequited love and was forced to hide his feelings, as the wedding attendants* returned to the bed-chamber,</l>
    .<l n="d">While his desire unfurled little by little, like the shoots of the <foreign>gaḍung</foreign> vine reaching towards the light of the moon.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The princess, goddess of love, in her confusion and distress, turned away, uneasily sighing as he tried to woo* her.</l>
    6285<l n="b">Sudden tears filled her eyes and, as they fell, seemed to turn to liquid honey.</l>
    .<l n="c">Her arching brows drew together in a frown as the prince embraced her,</l>
    .<l n="d">Her desperate heart crushed as he held her on his lap, sad and fearful as he tried to reassure her.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The prince, dejected by this, pondered deeply on how to win her affection.</l>
    6290<l n="b">Perplexed and agitated by his love, he passionately embraced her slender waist.</l>
    .<l n="c">Because of his joy, he felt impelled to listen* only to his heart, the seat of his strong desire,</l>
    .<l n="d">With a constant flood of sweet endearments and caresses which might woo her to the delights of love:</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘My darling, you have ever been the deity of my meditation [enthroned] in my love-sick heart. You are the Goddess of Love, Ratih, in human form.</l>
    6295<l n="b">You are the invisible essence which arises from the immaterial state of the depths of feeling of one who longs to know the secrets of the raptures of love.*</l>
    .<l n="c">You are the embodiment of honey, the goddess of flowers, the splendour of <foreign>asana </foreign>blossoms, the jewel of maidenhood,</l>
    .<l n="d">The beauty of the fourth month, a bejewelled statue transformed into a girl.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘So little sister, it seems that I have reached my goal now that I hold you on my lap and draw near to you.</l>
    6300<l n="b">You are the one I have longed for constantly and the reason I have sought to come to you now, to take you upon my knee.</l>
    .<l n="c">You are the very jewel of my heart, wherein is set the innermost kernel of my devotion to love.</l>
    .<l n="d">To achieve my purpose, I have risked all, that I might be one with you and succeed in enjoying your favour.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘But now I* am in despair, how can you repay me with but a glance, while I suffer under my unyielding desire?</l>
    6305<l n="b">See how my heart breaks as I hold back my love, though you could set me free with words of love.</l>
    .<l n="c">Clearly, my life must cease, for you have mortally wounded me, O jewel of the palace.</l>
    .<l n="d">Indeed, I have treasured the praise* of your charms in my dreams, but I grow weary at encountering only sullenness.’*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus, the prince cajoled her with words sweet enough to drive away the princess’s reluctance,</l>
    6310<l n="b">Like a frenzied bee whispering softly to a profusion of fragrant <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers that have not yet opened.</l>
    .<l n="c">Seeking to obtain happiness with soft words while inhaling her perfume, embracing her tightly,</l>
    .<l n="d">Full of passion but gentle, he bent his intent gaze on her, determined to seize her waist.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    6315<div type="canto" n="49">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">But the princess turned away from the prince’s sweet words of comfort,</l>
    .<l n="b">Taking no pleasure in the charm of his words as he caressed her.</l>
    .<l n="c">Full of doubt, she moved away as he whispered to her, and wept as he kissed her,</l>
    .<l n="d">Drawing her <foreign>tapih</foreign> tightly around her huddled body, afraid that he would suddenly seize upon the opening of her <foreign>kain</foreign>, that he eyed so intently.</l>
    6320</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Her angry glance, so beautiful it melted his heart, devastated her lover.</l>
    .<l n="b">The frowning arch of her eyebrows wounded him and the prince, wanting only to caress her, was saddened.</l>
    .<l n="c">Her efforts to resist him were like those of the shoots of the <foreign>aśoka</foreign> battling against the wind.</l>
    .<l n="d">Her movements were those of a lotus addressed with endearing names by a frenzied bee.</l>
    6325</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The prince’s heart was intoxicated, flooded with sweet delight at the princess’s beauty.</l>
    .<l n="b">Ever more passionately he caressed her, softly stroking her, though she remained indifferent.</l>
    .<l n="c">His hands crept towards her waist, aiming for her waist band,</l>
    .<l n="d">And he began, once again, to assail her with sweet sound, a deluge of loving words:</l>
    6330</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘My darling, you are the jewel of beauty who confuses my love-lorn heart.</l>
    .<l n="b">By your actions, you only enhance your sweetness and pierce me to the core.</l>
    .<l n="c">You constantly wound my loving heart which is ever ready to welcome your words of endearment,</l>
    .<l n="d">But, just like the moon, I cannot bring relief to an unopened flower bud, feverish with heat.’</l>
    6335</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘You are as beautiful as the <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers found in the floral hair band of a hair-knot, so sweet and fragrant.</l>
    .<l n="b">Joyfully, I long to awaken your love, but you want to hide your charming perfection.</l>
    .<l n="c">I am a bee, full of love, but weary of fighting off my passion and desire for so long,</l>
    .<l n="d">Fearlessly inhaling your scent, happy to die if I already wore the marks of being the first one to taste of [the flowers in] your hair-knot.</l>
    6340</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="50">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘Oh how disappointed am I in love and so I will tell of the nature of my wistful longing.</l>
    .<l n="b">It is unbearable, though my heart would beat a little faster if addressed with words of love.</l>
    6345<l n="c">Instead, I am full of ardent longing, because I embrace your waist and restlessly seek your approval,</l>
    .<l n="d">In the mistaken belief that you might be touched by passion, when you see the suffering of one who is so filled with desire.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘Oh I am overpowered with longing and have lost patience because of the urgings of the God of Love.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Thrown into confusion at the slightest touch of your finger tips or shapely calves, bewildered with desire,</l>
    6350<l n="c">My heart is flooded with desperation, I am rendered powerless by your hair-knot, I ache when your sweet eyes fall on me.</l>
    .<l n="d">I know not what to do. What can I say to persuade you to accept my words?’*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">But the princess’s thoughts were sad,* as the prince continually honoured her again with words.</l>
    .<l n="b">‘My darling wife, accept my care as I cradle you on my lap and hope to make love to you.</l>
    6355<l n="c">If you must deny me access to your smile, then scratch me instead with your sharp nails.</l>
    .<l n="d">I would rather die. What is death by comparison to the dangers faced in seeking refuge in the realm of love?</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">‘In short, behold the state of this lover who presents to you his words of love,</l>
    .<l n="b">Hoping always that in your love I might find the place I so tirelessly seek, where I can lay down my sorrow and passion.</l>
    6360<l n="c">I will stop without ever reaching my goal of having you as my support, O jewel amongst maidens,</l>
    .<l n="d">And it would be preferable for me to slink away in shame if you will not receive me kindly.’</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="51">
    6365<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">Thus said the prince. The princess moaned dejectedly,</l>
    .<l n="b">Powerless to resist the prince any longer, unable to ward off his persuasive words.</l>
    .<l n="c">The broken points of her nails were of no use and so, her efforts to resist him were easily defeated and brushed aside,</l>
    .<l n="d">And the prince persisted in his efforts to kiss her more and more passionately.</l>
    .</p>
    6370<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The princess was so confused, her resistance so ineffectual, her heart so anxious as she sighed,</l>
    .<l n="b">That it truly seemed her tears should have deterred the prince.</l>
    .<l n="c">But it was too much, she could no longer think of striking him, defeated, tired beyond measure,</l>
    .<l n="d">As the prince continued to shower her with words as sweet as the ocean of honey:</l>
    .</p>
    6375</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="52">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘Dear maiden, heart’s desire, give me the gift of your glance. Do not be cross or avert your gaze. Look at me!</l>
    .<l n="b">What a pity it is, my beloved, that in your anger, you do not care if I am suffering with desire or beset by pangs of love.</l>
    .<l n="c">Oh, do not weep, do not moan or be dejected, how can I continue to serve you, if you will not speak? </l>
    6380<l n="d">In short, how can you disappoint me so in my quest to obtain your support* to help me draw near to you?</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘It would be better if you would but bestow your sweetness on me, so that I might match it with my steadfast* love.</l>
    .<l n="b">For your whimpering is in vain and only makes you weary and distresses you. How can it possibly be right?</l>
    .<l n="c">Indeed, you only strike my breast and threaten me with your terrible nails and conceal the redness of your teeth.</l>
    6385<l n="d">Certainly, my dear, if you would but accept my approaches, I would find the proper way* to worship you.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Thus, Arjuna’s love became words of such sweetness that they would vanquish liquid sugar,</l>
    .<l n="b">His heart compelled him to restrain his longing no more, though she cried out, continually pushing him away.</l>
    .<l n="c">But the princess was too exhausted, deprived of all strength and her tears were to no avail as she fought him off.</l>
    6390<l n="d">She did not know what to do as the prince, approaching her from the side,* took her forcibly.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">In short, though the princess resisted him, she was powerless, distraught, as he took her by surprise,</l>
    .<l n="b">Undoing her clothing, releasing her fragrance as her beautiful <foreign>kris</foreign>-shaped waist was laid bare,</l>
    .<l n="c">So that Dhanañjaya became even more exhilarated at this foretaste of the love-making to come,</l>
    6395<l n="d">Just as the bee, catching the first glimpse of the beauty of an <foreign>asana</foreign>, is suddenly driven to sip its honey.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="53">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">After he had deflowered her, that most excellent of maidens was exhausted and weak.</l>
    6400<l n="b">The prince, desire unabated, cradled her, his heart full* of deep yearning.</l>
    .<l n="c">The beautiful girl was the embodiment of the splendour of a wilted lotus,</l>
    .<l n="d">But because she was so painfully affected as she sank down, he whispered sweet words to her.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The prince was even more disturbed by the princess,</l>
    6405<l n="b">As in the light of the lamps,* she seemed even more wan and pale.</l>
    .<l n="c">Now, so exhausted was she that she lay there as still as a statue of gold,</l>
    .<l n="d">As the prince gently embraced her, cradling her on his lap and rearranging her robe.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">But the woebegone princess dejectedly slipped away from him.</l>
    6410<l n="b">She was aghast at the blood glistening on her dress.</l>
    .<l n="c">So her adoring lover, not wanting to leave her side, carried her out</l>
    .<l n="d">To the outer verandah, going to find attendants to bathe her.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">Her maids were waiting, close at hand, with everything all prepared</l>
    6415<l n="b">And laid out in position for bathing her. All were skilled in understanding subtleties and giving guidance,</l>
    .<l n="c">All versed in soothing and bestowing great care on her.</l>
    .<l n="d">We will not tell of the goddess as she was bathed there beside her lover.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">After they had both been bathed, the girl who had now just experienced the intimacy of marriage,</l>
    6420<l n="b">Was petted and watched over* by her loving maid:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘Dear lady, resign yourself to bear a little pain,</l>
    .<l n="d">For your sorrow will soon turn to desire, my dear.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘The flowers of the fragrant lotus, jasmine and <foreign>nāgapuṣpa</foreign></l>
    6425<l n="b">Are nothing less than a sign* that it is appropriate</l>
    .<l n="c">For passionate bees to buzz around* them and ravish them.</l>
    .<l n="d">No mistress, I believe that being married is similar.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘Little one, you should return quickly to the pavilion. Oh, do go back my dear.</l>
    6430<l n="b">The one who yearns for you is held in thrall, and eagerly awaits you.’</l>
    .<l n="c">And she urged her so insistently that the princess was ashamed</l>
    .<l n="d">And mounted slowly back into the fragrant bridal chamber.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">On her return, the princess huddled in the farthest corner of the beautiful chamber.</l>
    6435<l n="b">The prince, with mounting joy, took her onto his lap,</l>
    .<l n="c">Caressing her and looking closely at her pale, drawn face,</l>
    .<l n="d">Then kissed her passionately, his sweet words falling like rain drops:</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    6440<div type="canto" n="54">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">‘You are the very relative of the moon, you are the rumbling of the thunder of desire, the gentle rain of the raptures of love.</l>
    .<l n="b">You bring me constant heartache, so that I burgeon with passion, and my love puts forth new shoots.</l>
    .<l n="c">Moreover,* as I embrace your charms, suddenly offering me flowers of desire,*</l>
    .<l n="d">My joy knows no limit in being intertwined with you in the reality of sexual union.</l>
    6445</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">‘Now see, beloved, how fortunate I am to be your partner and share love with you.</l>
    .<l n="b">You, my lady, signify the end of my earthly existence. You are the provisions I will carry to the next world as I lie next to you in repose.</l>
    .<l n="c">Indeed, in the hidden depths of your eyes, transfixed, I let myself be carried away on the tide of my yearning,</l>
    .<l n="d">And I, your humble slave, will die willing, by casting myself* into the sea of honey to be as one with your sweetness.’</l>
    6450</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="55">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">In this way, he calmed the princess as he sought to comfort her.</l>
    .<l n="b">Enchantingly, he cradled her head in his lap, giving her delicious betel-leaf, eagerly kissing her lips,</l>
    6455<l n="c">Brushing back her hair, skillfully bestowing great care on her,</l>
    .<l n="d">Holding her hand, never wearying of resting his eyes on the fullness of her breasts.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">All the while, softly, tremulously, he murmured love poems, wave upon wave of sweet sentiments,</l>
    .<l n="b">Alternating with the pleasure of passionately kissing her beautiful cheek. </l>
    6460<l n="c">With the sweetest expressions of love, he began all over again* to address her fondly,</l>
    .<l n="d">Disturbing the newly blossoming areca flower, filling her with the constant sound.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The union of the prince and most excellent princess, there on the bridal couch,</l>
    .<l n="b">Could be likened to that of the <foreign>mangunəng</foreign> and jasmine or the <foreign>katirah</foreign> touching the <foreign>wəlas-harəp</foreign> creeper,</l>
    6465<l n="c">As beautiful as the charming <foreign>gaḍung</foreign> entwining and merging with the <foreign>wanañjari.</foreign>*</l>
    .<l n="d">Such was their union, as they shared together in the raptures of love.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">The delighted prince abandoned himself to the pursuit of erotic pleasure, there on the couch,</l>
    .<l n="b">All night long, unable to sleep, so often did he caress the princess.</l>
    6470<l n="c">His words of love could be heard by the women hidden behind the curtains spying on them, and their sighs,</l>
    .<l n="d">And the constant tinkling of their anklets, told of their penetration into the secrets of sexual intercourse.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="56">
    6475<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The night passed and as day came, the bright light of the sun shone down.</l>
    .<l n="b">When it was time for the <foreign>kraban</foreign> ceremonies and everything was ready,</l>
    .<l n="c">Everything was so wondrous and incomparable that it seemed to have come from Indra’s heaven,</l>
    .<l n="d">For it was King Harimūrti who had ordered them to be prepared and had seen to their arrangement.</l>
    .</p>
    6480<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The exquisite seven fragrances,* deer-navel musk and sandalwood spread over all,</l>
    .<l n="b">Bringing enchantment to the girl who had for the first time known a man there on the couch.</l>
    .<l n="c">Incense glowed, its vapour seemed to waft* there to enhance the delight,</l>
    .<l n="d">Seeking out the radiance of the <foreign>cawəli</foreign> silk of the curtains, always so fragrant.</l>
    .</p>
    6485<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">The delightful melodies of <foreign>kidung,</foreign> accompanied on the lute, began to play,</l>
    .<l n="b">Sounding so much like bees that everyone thought it was spring.</l>
    .<l n="c">Then as these constant offerings seemed to increase in splendour, their thoughts turned again to love,</l>
    .<l n="d">An experience so wondrous that it laid to rest her fear of love-making.</l>
    .</p>
    6490<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">In full view, the two went out and sat side-by-side on the verandah.</l>
    .<l n="b">After they had bathed and put on their jewels and ornaments,</l>
    .<l n="c">They looked as sweet as the conjoined beauty of the lotus and honey,</l>
    .<l n="d">Bearing with fortitude* the presence of the maids, all of whom were beautiful and were wearing many <foreign>maṇḍaga</foreign>* ornaments.</l>
    .</p>
    6495<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">Finally a gentle elderly lady* from the palace charged with* their care,</l>
    .<l n="b">Who was learned* in interpreting auspicious signs, summoned them to come forth.</l>
    .<l n="c">And so the two then stood up and came out to the audience hall,</l>
    .<l n="d">Where the Yadu tribe was being sumptuously entertained as they feasted outside.</l>
    .</p>
    6500<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">To tell of all that took place would take too long. As day departed,</l>
    .<l n="b">The bridal pair moved away together to the beautiful pavilion where they would spend the night.</l>
    .<l n="c">People thought of them as the beautiful <foreign>asana</foreign> flower and the bee,</l>
    .<l n="d">As the two lovers devoted themselves to each other with caresses, shared comforts and sweet whisperings.</l>
    .</p>
    6505<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">The princess’s apprehension then ceased as her love unfolded</l>
    .<l n="b">Because the sweet prince completely won over her downcast heart.</l>
    .<l n="c">Like the deep joy of ivory bamboo when it comes into contact with the rain from the clouds,</l>
    .<l n="d">Desire pierced her, filling her to the core, as she became one with the prince.</l>
    .</p>
    6510<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">It was the same for the prince, as he sought release from passion in their sexual union,</l>
    .<l n="b">A devotee of loving, that reached perfection there on the couch.</l>
    .<l n="c">His languid sidelong glance was the box of sacrifical unguent he placed on her firm breasts*</l>
    .<l n="d">And his caresses were the acts of worship arising from his invocation of the presence of the god in their sexual union.*</l>
    .</p>
    6515<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Later, they ate the delicious food that lay ready.</l>
    .<l n="b">The food, drink and delicacies were quite perfect.</l>
    .<l n="c">Any wonderful gift, anything at all that they desired, was there</l>
    .<l n="d">Because of Kr̥ṣṇa, the paramount, heroic king, who was the embodiment on earth of the incarnation of the eight kingly virtues.</l>
    .</p>
    6520</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="57">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">And so it was that their union was a thing of joy.</l>
    .<l n="b">Never wearying of each other, one in spirit were they in the interchange of love and passion.</l>
    .<l n="c">Many months went by. Their every action was in harmony,</l>
    6525<l n="d">Their happiness grew with the burgeoning of their great love.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will pass over the description of their marriage.</l>
    .<l n="b">The twelfth year of exile came and went.</l>
    .<l n="c">Phalguṇa’s mind then turned to thoughts</l>
    6530<l n="d">Of those he had left behind.* How could he now abandon them?</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">It is in the nature of existence that the pain of separation cannot prevail.*</l>
    .<l n="b">Great longing then subtly takes up residence in the heart</l>
    .<l n="c">So that sorrow and loss of peace of mind take possession of it,</l>
    6535<l n="d">And it may happen that one forgets the gifts of the wheel of existence.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">And so Pārtha’s mind was troubled</l>
    .<l n="b">And he said to his bride:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘My darling wife, my little sister, you are indeed my very being.</l>
    6540<l n="d">O my lady, you purge my longing and put an end to my sorrow.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">‘But now increasingly my own desires defer to</l>
    .<l n="b">My great devotion to my beloved mother* and brothers.</l>
    .<l n="c">Because for so long now I have left them abandoned,</l>
    6545<l n="d">I think only of what has become of them in the palace there.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">‘But my devotion to you, my dear is ever constant.</l>
    .<l n="b">I wish to share your love. Come with me to my own home,</l>
    .<l n="c">And stay with me there in Indraprastha. My dear, have no fear.</l>
    6550<l n="d">Our hearts will find perfect peace in living in accordance with what is right, my darling.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">‘So here is the course we must take, my beloved.</l>
    .<l n="b">It is my duty to pay homage in the dust at the feet of the King </l>
    .<l n="c">And your place is to be beside me as my faithful and beloved wife.</l>
    6555<l n="d">And thus you too may properly carry out the wishes of Yudhisthira, the son of Dharma.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">Thus said the prince, lovingly addressing her with kind and gentle words.</l>
    .<l n="b">So the princess gave him answer, her voice faltering:</l>
    .<l n="c">‘O my Lord, I know what you say is virtuous and right.</l>
    6560<l n="d">How could I not follow the proper duty of a wife?</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">‘It is only that I am bewildered, torn in two by how I will suffer and yearn</l>
    .<l n="b">Greatly for my own mother and my lord the king, </l>
    .<l n="c">Not forgetting my brothers, who call to me with longing, holding me back.</l>
    6565<l n="d">I cannot repay their love by bringing them grief.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">‘My devotion to my parents is beyond words</l>
    .<l n="b">Truly it as great as both the mountains, Hima and Sumeru.</l>
    .<l n="c">But if I told of my love for you,</l>
    6570<l n="d">It would truly be wider than the widest ocean.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="11"><l n="a">We will say no more of their conversation</l>
    .<l n="b">After they had agreed to the prince’s resolution.</l>
    .<l n="c">That night they slept in mutual delight in the fragrant bed,</l>
    6575<l n="d">Their hearts absorbed in joining together in desire, swept away by passion.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="58">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The next morning, the prince and his beloved awoke and came out from the bower.</l>
    6580<l n="b">They went to the water-spouts where they bathed joyfully together.</l>
    .<l n="c">When they left the water, they gently stroked each other’s faces, blowing into each other’s eyes,*</l>
    .<l n="d">Arranging flowers here and there,* he decorated the princess’s fragrant hair-knot.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">After adorning themselves fittingly, they came forth hand-in-hand, strolling away together.</l>
    6585<l n="b">It seemed that Manmatha, the god of the love-couch, was present in his eyes and in his sweet teeth.</l>
    .<l n="c">There, on the tiled verandah, they sat together with thighs touching,</l>
    .<l n="d">And any who saw the princess sitting on his lap, exchanging chewed betel, thought they were the God and Goddess of Love.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">‘If I were to die, how delightful it would be if I could return as a bee.</l>
    6590<l n="b">I could passionately enjoy your charms for ever, if they were in the fragrant <foreign>asana</foreign> flowers in the garden.</l>
    .<l n="c">I would know ecstasy even if the <foreign>gaḍing</foreign> repulsed and wounded me or I were struck down by a rain of honey.</l>
    .<l n="d">If I died, but bore the signs of my joy at making love to you, I would have reached heaven.’*</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">This was the way Pārtha spoke, his words as sweet as the incarnation of syrup.</l>
    6595<l n="b">Delighted and full of ardent longing, he entwined the fingers of her hand, then reached out* to encircle her waist.</l>
    .<l n="c">Like the <foreign>jangga</foreign> embracing the slender young shoots of the ivory coconut, he softly directed himself to her ear,</l>
    .<l n="d">But the goddess turned away sighing again, languishing as the prince caressed her.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">We will not tell of their love. Finally they came forth, making their way to the inner court.</l>
    6600<l n="b">There the prince and the most excellent princess entered the presence of king Basudewa who was there with Halāyudha</l>
    .<l n="c">And Lord Kr̥ṣṇa. The lovers both came there,</l>
    .<l n="d">And bowed reverently at the king’s feet. He at once received Dhanañjaya benevolently.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">The prince paid obeisance: ‘I beg you, O King, to hear my request.</l>
    6605<l n="b">I seek leave to return to my home and therefore, I, your humble servant,* kiss your feet.</l>
    .<l n="c">Please do not think that I am ungrateful or indifferent, or that I wish to cast aside your favour</l>
    .<l n="d">Or seem to neglect my duty, for indeed, those who would be freed from their bonds face great difficulties.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">After Dhanañjaya had begged leave, the king embraced him:</l>
    6610<l n="b">‘Oh my son, I understand, my boy, that your heart is firm in our cause.</l>
    .<l n="c">But if you must go, then I shall divide my kingdom, lands and possessions,</l>
    .<l n="d">And all the most excellent things that befit a king throughout our kingdom you will enjoy, now you are close-bound* to us.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">‘Indeed always be generous, my son, when you see the worthlessness of those who have no protection, show them compassion.</l>
    6615<l n="b">May you never encounter difficulty, or be neglectful of the teachings, cruel in your affections, or harsh.</l>
    .<l n="c">My daughter, apply yourself well, for clearly it is your duty to serve your lord and show him every care,</l>
    .<l n="d">And thus you will come to know the love of Kuntī, your Lady Aunt* and elder brothers if you always bear in mind the duties of a younger person.’</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">Thus was his advice, and the prince, who thought it was like the water of life, then bowed* in reverent acknowledgement.</l>
    6620<l n="b">Lord Kr̥ṣṇa declared that he would accompany them home, because he loved them so.</l>
    .<l n="c">Nor did Baladewa wish to be left behind, he too wanted to go with the prince</l>
    .<l n="d">But resolutely the prince denied them, saying that in the future they would certainly visit.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    6625<div type="canto" n="59">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">We will not tell of their deliberation.</l>
    .<l n="b">Away sped a messenger carrying the king’s words</l>
    .<l n="c">To Yudhiṣṭhira and his consort,</l>
    .<l n="d">Making his way to the kingdom of Indraprastha.</l>
    6630</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">We will not tell of the departure of the royal messenger</l>
    .<l n="b">But again tell of Pārtha.</l>
    .<l n="c">From the court he returned to his quarters,</l>
    .<l n="d">Where many members of the Wr̥ṣṇi family visited him with offers of assistance.</l>
    6635</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Their offerings as they came to pay homage were delightful.</l>
    .<l n="b">All were weeping, so filled were they with love,</l>
    .<l n="c">Their affectionate natures dominating them and overwhelming them</l>
    .<l n="d">With constant thoughts of love for the princess.</l>
    6640</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">And as for the princess, she too was moved to tears</l>
    .<l n="b">And wept bitterly, her heart moved by compassion,</l>
    .<l n="c">Disheartened and saddened now that separation was imminent,</l>
    .<l n="d">Not knowing what to think, suddenly beginning to lament.</l>
    6645</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="60">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">The ladies of the court who together were charged with the regulation of affairs* in the inner chamber,</l>
    .<l n="b">Were frantically busy, for suddenly, not only did they have to make preparations but also apply themselves to embroidery.*</l>
    6650<l n="c">But we will not describe those who were to accompany them to Indraprastha, all were impatient to go.</l>
    .<l n="d">All through the night came a quiet hum as they threaded strings of ornaments very carefully.*</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="61">
    6655<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">We will not tell of this. The next morning, at the appointed time, when the countryside was fresh,</l>
    .<l n="b">Pārtha bid farewell and set off with his beloved.</l>
    .<l n="c">Together, all watched them climb into their seats in their chariot,</l>
    .<l n="d">As with Dāruki, their charioteer, at the ready, they left in magnificent and splendid style.</l>
    .</p>
    6660<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">The Wr̥ṣṇi troops, who would be the guard on their journey, were prepared and at the ready.</l>
    .<l n="b">Immediately they too set off from the palace, in a procession of chariots,</l>
    .<l n="c">Leaving those left behind so despondent that they could only stare anxiously after them,</l>
    .<l n="d">Lost in thought and grieving, as if they longed to set off after them and go too.</l>
    .</p>
    6665<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">Great indeed was their yearning. But we will tell now of the son of Pāṇḍu.</l>
    .<l n="b">On and on he journeyed, past settlements they took their course.</l>
    .<l n="c">The countryside through which they passed was beautiful, and again and again he stopped along the way so that they might disport,</l>
    .<l n="d">Thinking up all kinds of excuses* to comfort his beloved’s heartache.</l>
    .</p>
    6670<p rend="stanza" n="4"><l n="a">They came upon many different villages, and all were expecting them,</l>
    .<l n="b">Ready to offer tribute, for indeed the prince was truly a man of distinction endowed with every good quality.</l>
    .<l n="c">Thus, there was no hesitation at all because he repaid them joyfully with royal grants,</l>
    .<l n="d">And all surrendered their hearts in homage and respect to him.</l>
    .</p>
    6675<p rend="stanza" n="5"><l n="a">It would take too long to tell of the time they spent on the road, stopping overnight here and there.</l>
    .<l n="b">They came to Indraprastha where they were welcomed by the whole court,</l>
    .<l n="c">Chief amongst them Kuntī and the sons of Pāṇḍu, with Yudhisthira in first place.</l>
    .<l n="d">‘It is like a ray of light in the darkness’, thought the people throughout the land.</l>
    .</p>
    6680<p rend="stanza" n="6"><l n="a">Without further ado, Lady Kuntī delightedly embraced Pārtha’s bride.</l>
    .<l n="b">Because she had looked forward so eagerly to their arrival,</l>
    .<l n="c">All she could say was: ‘My dear daughter! My son!’ so moved that her tears began to flow</l>
    .<l n="d">And deluged the hair-knots of the two who paid her homage there before her.</l>
    .</p>
    6685<p rend="stanza" n="7"><l n="a">As for Dharmatanaya, he too was full of joy,</l>
    .<l n="b">As were Bhīma, the heroic Nakula and his brother, all were also overjoyed</l>
    .<l n="c">To see Pārtha, returning as a world conqueror to his family, </l>
    .<l n="d">Moreover, he had won the world-renowned goddess of the Yadu tribe.</l>
    .</p>
    6690<p rend="stanza" n="8"><l n="a">It would take so long to describe the happiness of the king and all the court.</l>
    .<l n="b">The five sons of Pāṇḍu returned together to the palace,</l>
    .<l n="c">Accompanied by Kuntī. Ever at the side of Subhadrā, Pārtha’s wife,</l>
    .<l n="d">Was the Lady Dropadī, who looked to her needs and was full of affection for her.</l>
    .</p>
    6695<p rend="stanza" n="9"><l n="a">The homage that had been prepared for them was extraordinary.</l>
    .<l n="b">They were received with prayers of good fortune by the court priests and the foremost among learned religious leaders.</l>
    .<l n="c">The feasting and ceremonies were perfect,</l>
    .<l n="d">And all the ladies of noble birth, overcome with love, were happy to serve them.</l>
    .</p>
    6700<p rend="stanza" n="10"><l n="a">And thus Phalguṇa returned, his fame yet more renowned.</l>
    .<l n="b">Ever more safe and sound was that most excellent kingdom, now restored to prosperity, knowing no impediment.</l>
    .<l n="c">The members of each caste and stage of life,* as well as all the common people knew good fortune once again, as they had before.</l>
    .<l n="d">Yudhistira, son of Dharma, in his most wondrous and excellent majesty, was the parasol protecting the whole world.</l>
    .</p>
    6705</div>
    .<div type="canto" n="62">
    .<p rend="stanza" n="1"><l n="a">He* was as perfect as god Indra. How could his power, that so abounded in goodness, be surpassed?</l>
    .<l n="b">Shamed, the evil-doers stopped. They were destroyed and good men prospered.</l>
    .<l n="c">The admonitions of the great seer were undiminished, for he had instructed them in the proper course for those cursed to rely on the senses.*</l>
    6710<l n="d">In short, the four brothers were the source of his strength, while the sage kept watch over the eldest among them always.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="2"><l n="a">Blameless was he, occupying himself constantly with his subjects, fostering <foreign>dharma</foreign> like a light in the darkness of the land.</l>
    .<l n="b">Renowned throughout the world for his great courage, his might ever the strong protection of the world.</l>
    .<l n="c">As long as the <foreign>kṣatriya</foreign> warriors lived in righteousness, no evil could befall those who led the hermit’s life.</l>
    6715<l n="d">In prosperity, he was the place of refuge for the helpless, caring for them, succouring them.</l>
    .</p>
    .<p rend="stanza" n="3"><l n="a">And so, now here ends the story in praise of him who is the caretaker of the world.</l>
    .<l n="b">It is called <foreign>The Journeying of Pārtha</foreign>, the work of one who humbly seeks help and audaciously presumes to imitate [great poets].</l>
    .<l n="c">Deficient though it is, may it be received by the most excellent of men, may he not take offence at it, even though it is without merit.</l>
    6720<l n="d">May His Majesty, Surawīrya, have compassion and give his blessing to my efforts to capture beauty in verse.</l>
    .</p>
    .</div>
    . </div>
    . <div type="commentary">
    6725 <!-- Comment regarding your edition such as the following example -->
    . <!-- <p>The asterisk * is used to flag lemmata or forms of lemmata not recorded in the <title>Old Javanese-English Dictionary</title>.</p>-->
    . </div>
    . <div type="bibliography">
    . <p>Edited and translated by Creese (1998). Digital data furnished by the author processed tgo XML-TEI by Axelle Janiak and Arlo Griffiths (2025).</p>

    .<bibl/></listBibl>-->
    6735 </div>
    . </body>
    . </text>
    .</TEI>
    .
    ḍīpa
    ḍipa
